		<username>Nancy_Grease</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A Box Office Hit Crippled By Negative Press</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Roland Emmerich's Godzilla isn't the Toho character we all know and love. It's a beautifully crafted reimagining of the famed monster rendered to life with the artistry of CG for American audiences (although Godzilla went on to become the third top grossing film of 1998 based on world-wide box office). Critic however were not so generous. Reviews were largely negative and generations of fans who adored the original Toho movies were greatly disappointed by the changes rendered in the creature design and Emmerich's approach to the material. Toho has since adopted the film into the Godzilla universe, rebranding the monster Zilla. Zilla went on to a popular animated series in addition to appearing in Godzilla: Final Wars. As for Godzilla 1998, it remains an action packed adventure despite the negative press. Well worth a look.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2014-06-02</date>
		<username>xamtaro</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>An enjoyable monster movie. But bad Godzilla movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before the critically acclaimed GODZILLA 2014, Hollywood had attempted an Americanized remake of the classic Japanese monster back in 1998. They turned to Roland Emmerich, the man responsible for turning old B movie genres (alien invasion, otherworldly adventures and genetically enhanced soldiers) into big blockbuster hits. Hoping that he would do the same for the giant monster movie. To that end, Hollywood gave him Godzilla, the much beloved Japanese giant monster, to remake to his vision.Americanized, neutered and changed beyond recognition, GODZILLA came out as a decent monster movie, but a disappointing Godzilla movie. That issue lies in the portrayal of the titular Titan. Gone is the thought provoking nuclear disaster allegory, replaced by a feeble "man is the real monster" Aesop. Nuclear tests in the 1960s gave rise to a giant mutant bisexual lizard. This creature makes a beeline for Manhattan where his arrival is met with mass hysteria and chaos. Named "Godzilla" by the media (thanks to a misinterpreted comment from a dying Japanese sailor), America sends wave after wave of military hardware against the beast, causing more destruction than ever but failing to bring it down. Into this chaos comes dr Nick Tatopolus, an expert on radiation mutations. As the military tracks the monster through new york's concrete jungle, nick discovers that the creature may not be the only one of its kind for much longer. The hunt is on with French secret agents, a budding romance with a wannabe reporter and a parody of some well known movie critics all thrown in. The first thing that stood out for me in this movie was how enjoyable the scenes with the human characters were. Like INDEPENDENCE DAY, Roland Emmerich peppers this movie with a healthy dose of humor. This makes the one dimensional characters less of a pain to sit through. Hank Azaria, Kevin Dunn, Henry Shearer, all renown comedians, shine in their respective roles, delivering appropriate drama and laughs. Even Jean Reno does well as the offensively stereotyped French agent Philippe. Their scenes are fun, making an overall cliché ridden story more enjoyable than it is. Only the lead characters turn out a tad flat. Dr Nick, played by baby faced Matthew Broderick, brings his best "wide eyed" expressions to play as a man child caught up in the wonder of this giant beast yet running for his very life so he does not become dinner. Wide eyed shock, wide eyed awe, wide eyed terror, that seems to be his only expression. And the redundancy of Maria Pitillo's character Audrey cannot be understated.Of course, the true star of any Godzilla movie is Godzilla himself. This leaner, faster, velociraptor inspired look by designer Patrick Tatopolus is a terrific looking beast brought to life by cutting edge special effects. For a 1998 production, the effects still hold up well till today. The creature is elegant yet menacing, grand yet grim, with twin rows of fierce spikes on it's back, unbelievable agility and that trademark big chin that is common in Patrick Tatopolus' designs (eg: underworld's Lycans, pitch black's creatures, outlander's moorwen). However, it just isn't Godzilla, the unstoppable force of nature. It shows none of Godzilla's powers, nor his intelligence, nor his durability. Where the original Godzilla would be unfazed by missiles, smash tanks and planes out of his way, and carry on, this remade Godzilla squeals, runs and hides! Perhaps it would not have gotten that much hate had it been billed as a remake of THE BEAST FROM 20,000 FATHOMS, rather than a Godzilla movie. The basic plot of a lost giant creature drawn to New York and ultimately taken down by sheer luck and superior military firepower already mimics the broad strokes of that stop motion classic. Godzilla can easily pass off as a redesigned Rhedrosaur. But alas, here it is billed as a Godzilla movie. As a Godzilla movie, Roland Emmerich's multi million dollar blockbuster would rank in the lower thirds. Better than the likes of GODZILLA VS MEGALON, GODZILLA's REVENGE, GODZILLA FINAL WAR and GIGANTIS THE FIRE MONSTER. But compared to the rest of the Heisei era Godzilla movies, the early millennium era, and especially the original 1954 classic, this American remake is a disappointment. So disappointing in fact that the titular Titan of a lizard has been officially renamed "Zilla" by the original creators of the Godzilla franchise. I for one enjoyed this purely as a modern monster movie. It entertains, it has cool special effects, and it is good fun. Nothing much else though.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2014-05-12</date>
		<username>alex wolfman</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>This is "guilty pleasure" fun indeed.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In 1954, the new film "Godzilla" hit the theaters in Japan and made an impact that nobody foresaw or thought would have happened. Sure, in 1933 the famous King Kong was released but Godzilla was still an inspiration for many monster films to follow. These movies include the classic 1954 movie, "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea" and even more recent films including the 2006 South Korean film, "The Host" and "Cloverfield" from 2008. So many monster movies world-wide have been inspired by the original Godzilla movie.In my mind, around the 1990's, we were long overdue for an American Godzilla film for many years. It is true that in 1956, there was an American production of Godzilla, King of the Monsters! but it had mostly the same footage from the original Godzilla to introduce the monster Godzilla to an American audience. It would seem that a new American version would surely find an audience in the States and create a new audience so to generate sequels.In 1998, an American version of Godzilla was indeed released. It came with a risk because of the past history of Godzilla movies and it also needed a big budget to properly depict this large monster. In the end, this movie version of Godzilla is mostly hated but I was able to look past this.After a sudden and mysterious attack on a Japanese vessel and also some big footprints found in the Panamanian forests, Dr. Nick Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) is contacted by the U.S. State Department who discovered a giant mystery which a monster we later called Godzilla and who's main target for attack is the Big Apple, New York City. This is an attack that later turns into much more.At the time of the movies release, director Roland Emmerich was coming off the huge success of Independence Day and there was much hype surround this film because of that. He brought Matthew Broderick in for the lead role but I believe Broderick is a questionable lead because he has never been the action film actor and his inexperience in this genre shows in this movie. Emmerich also casts popular television actor Hank Azaria as Victor Palotti as a funny guy but he mostly meanders around and is not very funny. Maria Pitillo is the love interest of Dr. Tatopoulos but her acting here is a mess and she gives some clear reasons as to why she's not around in films any more.At first glance, it seems like this is a simple plot but the plot does have some substance. Even though New York City comes off as a simple setting, the film does give us many interesting shots of the city during it's action scenes. The action scenes don't really stand out and the ending is tiresome but the action here is enough to get by. Popular actor Jean Reno plays an very interesting French secret agent which adds a foreign spy angle to this new Godzilla.What's becomes even more interesting about this American remake is the Godzilla creature itself. Godzilla sure looks like a dinosaur and that maybe is understandable considering this film was made during the heights of the popularity of Jurassic Park. The special effects here are hit or miss. The film does sets itself up perfectly for sequels but these were late canceled due to the poor audience reaction to this movie. There is also a baby element which later turns into a type of biology lesson that involves asexual reproduction. As you can see, the substance of this movie is kind of all over the place but it sure does add some elements to a film that could have easily been too simple.In the end, this is a somewhat standard Roland Emmerich film. The movie is very dumb at times and has many problems but in the end Godzilla works in a cheesy kind of way. This was a silly action film from the 90's that I wish had found it's audience. This is "guilty pleasure" fun indeed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Whats with all the hate?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I remember the days of being a young child, Godzilla was everything to me back then. Of course I had to order all the films off of ebay or be lucky enough to find one at the video store, but this was easy to have seen. As a child I was completely thrilled by this film and even cried at the ending when I was young, but have since turned my back on to it after I read all these reviews hating it, what were they looking for, the meaning of life? Get real it's a monster movie. I finally picked up the Blu-ray and I must say it was still a blast, I recommend the Blu-ray, it enhances the action scenes very well. Sure the characters were mediocre and the dialogue is a hit or a miss, but I can look past that. The visual's still look decent and the special effects are cool to see. This film is not a Godzilla film, he is very different from the original, mainly he can be injured from missiles. I kind of like his design here, it's not bad. The ending was a set up to a sequel that never happened. But of course there was the animated series. I would have loved a sequel were he fought another monster. Comparing the two Godzilla's is a no brain'er, the Japanese one is superior in every way. I could go on for a few more paragraphs of talking about this, but instead I'm going to cut it short. It's a fun movie and is very entertaining. Give it a watch, but keep in mind it's just a monster movie and should not be viewed as anything else.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A Plot less Piece of Trash</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why did I expect anything from this movie? Roland Emmerich directed it. But the original Godzilla was just so good, why can't it ever stick true to the original 1954 version? 	<review>
		<date>2011-06-25</date>
		<username>Jimmy L.</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>One of Hollywood's most expensive sci-fi B-movies?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's obvious that Roland Emmerich's GODZILLA (1998) aims to update the old and sometimes campy Japanese man-in-a-rubber-suit monster movies as a blockbuster disaster flick for modern American audiences. And who better to do it than the man behind the blockbuster alien invasion flick INDEPENDENCE DAY (1996)?(Emmerich would direct later world-in-peril films THE DAY AFTER TOMORROW (2004) and 2012 (2009).)Emmerich's movie brings the giant Atomic Age reptile to contemporary New York City (instead of Tokyo), a move designed to engage U.S. audiences. In Manhattan, among the skyscrapers and tunnel system, the creature has found an ideal hiding spot. Between the ginormous reptile swinging his tail around and the army offensive, much of New York is laid to waste. (Which is interesting to see, as this film was made prior to the 2001 tragedies, when it was alright to destroy New York landmarks on screen.)GODZILLA stays pretty close to the tradition of the low-budget sci-fi B-movies of the 1950s (started by THE BEAST FROM 20,000 FATHOMS (1953), etc.), albeit bloated with blockbuster dollars. The story follows the tried-and-true formula: scientist/military personnel track an unknown threat by piecing together reports of unusual activity across the globe, monster appears in heavily populated and well-known urban setting, initial attacks on the monster prove futile, etc., etc. Set up as a summer tentpole, this movie takes the formula of its B-movie forefathers and expands it into a 139-minute extravaganza of exciting action and special effects.As with those earlier films, the star is the monster. The characters serve their purpose, but are merely pieces to the puzzle. Cookie-cutter archetypes. Here the cast includes Matthew Broderick (FERRIS BUELLER'S DAY OFF) as The Scientist Who Figures It Out, Kevin Dunn (TRANSFORMERS) as The Colonel Coordinating The Attacks, Jean Reno (LEON: THE PROFESSIONAL) as The Mysterious French Agent, Maria Pitillo (GODZILLA) as the Love Interest/News Reporter, and Hank Azaria (NIGHT AT THE MUSEUM: BATTLE OF THE SMITHSONIAN) as the Fearless Cameraman. The characters in the 1950s B-movies were often bland, but the characters in GODZILLA are sprinkled with little quirks. Broderick is eccentric and has a name nobody can pronounce (Niko Tatopoulos). Azaria is the prototypical Italian Knicks-loving New Yorker, and he wears a hat. The mayor (Michael Lerner) is a celebrity lookalike with a sweet tooth. The army sergeant (Doug Savant) is humorously unsure of himself. Vicki Lewis (TV's "NewsRadio") adds charm to the research team and Harry Shearer (THIS IS SPINAL TAP) plays a slimy TV news anchor.The acting is second-rate and the script is full of the clichés viewers have come to expect from these types of films. The money was spent on the special effects. The story does touch upon some interesting things, like using modern heat-seeking missiles against a cold-blooded target, Godzilla underwater, and the possible threat of baby 'zillas. There's an ominous atmosphere to the proceedings, and many fun little moments. Matthew Broderick is an odd choice for the leading man in an actioner like this, but he's amusing at times. Jean Reno's character is pretty cool. It's no ALIENS (1986) or JURASSIC PARK (1993), but the movie is exciting despite its flaws.The visual effects are the real show here.Taking advantage of the latest technology, this new GODZILLA sought to thrill audiences with a spectacle unlike any other. And the big-budget effects are pretty effective overall. They certainly did the job at the time, following in the footsteps of recent action/disaster movies. An advancement from the rubber suit, the CGI Godzilla was ambitious, but looks something less than photorealistic to jaded eyes today.Purists were disappointed by the film's redesigned Godzilla and the New York setting, as well as the whole pregnancy thing (among a laundry list of infractions). They claimed that Emmerich's giant monster movie bore little resemblance to the long-running Godzilla franchise. The original Japanese GOJIRA (1954) was a cautionary tale about atomic power, inspired by the WWII bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Sequels introduced new monsters and alien creatures to the colorful Godzilla world. This updated version is a run-of-the-mill, modern-day, effects- laden disaster movie. Although there are moments that attempt to evoke a certain sympathy for the misunderstood monster (? la KING KONG), this movie is all about knocking buildings down and chomping on helicopters.I was reminded of GODZILLA (1998) while recently watching the low-budget THE BEAST FROM 20,000 FATHOMS (1953). BEAST is the groundbreaking monster-attacks-city movie about a prehistoric dinosaur who goes on a rampage after being awakened by hydrogen bomb tests at the north pole. Featuring wonderful stop-motion animation creature effects by Ray Harryhausen, BEAST predated the earliest Japanese Godzilla movie, possibly influencing the entire genre. Perhaps the biggest connection between that movie and this one is that the giant reptiles choose to attack New York City, after wreaking havoc in the ocean. Other similarities probably come with the territory. In redesigning the iconic Godzilla and placing him in New York, GODZILLA comes across more as a remake of BEAST than the Japan-centric Godzillas.Many viewers seem disappointed in Roland Emmerich's GODZILLA, but I must say it does its job. It is very much like Emmerich's other awe- inspiring destruction flicks. This time, instead of aliens or natural disasters, it's a towering radioactive lizard. Seen apart from its famous brand, this is a fairly entertaining popcorn movie. Big lizard, large-scale property damage, explosions, cutting-edge visual effects, thrills and chills. What more do you need? Admittedly the plot and characters are nothing very special, but the action keeps you interested. Sometimes it's good just to sit back and enjoy the magic of the movies. Extraordinary tales brought to life. An escape from the hum-drum real world. GODZILLA does alright.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>Godzilla in NYC</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK for starters i'm probably the only Godzilla fan in the world who liked this film. the plot concerns a group of scientists (Dr. Niko Tatopoulos ,Dr. Elsie Chapman and Dr. Mendel Craven) who have been rounded up by Colonel Hicks to study Godzilla an iguana irradiated by nuclear tests. it is also the first of its kind and it decides no make NYC it's nesting grounds for the thousands of eggs it was soon to lay. here in NYC is also where we find Audrey Timmonds nick's college girlfriend and Victor "Animal" Palotti a camera man who is a friend of Audrey. now since Godzilla invaded NYC obviously it would be the news story of a lifetime so Audrey and victor decide to try and get it on tape and victor is almost crushed by Godzilla's foot in the process. soon after Godzilla's first attack mayor Eberto (played by none other than ...well Eberto)decides to evacuate the city and find a way to put a halt on Godzilla permanently. meanwhile hicks nick Elsy and craven decide what the best way to stop Godzilla would be the nick suggests that the best way to stop Godzilla is not to force him out but to draw him out. so they decide to use mountains of fish so Godzilla will smell the bate and come to them. the plan works but also backfires seeming as Godzilla escapes destroys 4 choppers and in the process destroys the Chrysler building. after this happens we see nick and Audrey in the tent discussing the creature when Audrey decides to steal a top secret tape of Early footage of Godzilla never seen before. then after her story is seen on TV by the army they decide to boot him out of the assignment. as nick leaves new york Audrey tries to apologize but unfortunately nick isn't so forgiving seeing as this is the second time Audrey has emotionally scarred nick.after this happens the army hunts down and finally manages to kill Godzilla with the shot of a submarine torpedo. when nick leaves NYC the cab driver kidnapped him and tells him his name is Philippe Roche and wants to find the eggs that Godzilla has laid as much as nick dose. when they are seen at the base of Philippe and his men it is soon discovered that they are not alone and that victor has been spying on them. after this discovery victor decides to tell Audrey that nick is planning to destroy the eggs and he wants Audrey to come with him to tell the world of nick's heroics surly enough she agrees and they follow nick and the others to Madison square garden where the eggs have been laid. soon the thousands of eggs begin to hatch and Audrey and victor meet up with nick and Philippe where they participate in a chase throughout the garden and are hunted down by the baby Godzilla's. soon they find a camera hooked up to the news station Audrey works at and they use it to contact the army for help. it is then discovered that they have less than 6 minutes to escape before the building blows up. our heroes get away but a shocking discovery is made that Godzilla never died and chased nick and the others to the Brooklyn bridge where they all take place in a car chase across the bridge.soon the army is notified and finally destroy the creature on the bridge as our heroes just manage to escape. but after Godzilla is dead it turns out that there is one last egg and it was set up for a sequel that never happened but there was an animated series that continued the story that i also highly recommend. all in all i don't get Way everyone hated this film so much i can understand being disappointed by the fact that Godzilla doesn't have his trademark atomic breath but other than that its a fun entertaining movie and is Roland's finest work in my opinion. great flick check it out.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Whoever made this movie, has never seen a Godzilla movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, seriously, what the crap. This movie is a fail. The monster doesn't even deserve the name "Godzilla". Then Japan just called it Z.i.l.l.a. It doesn't even deserve to have part of Godzilla's name in it. The army beats the monster, excuse my language, but WHAT THE CRAP! The army defeats him. 28 Japan Godzilla movies Godzilla doesn't care about the army, they are just like, poking him! But in this movie, Godzilla gets hurt by the army. Most people that say that this movie is awesome have just never seen the rich quality of the real Godzilla movies. And then we see that Godzilla had 200 babies. He only had like 2 from the original series! The one thing that makes me want to set fire to places that sell this movie is the fact that Godzilla has those spikes on his back that normally would've powered his fire (or nuclear) breath! Not including that is seriously like making a spider-man movie when he doesn't shoot webs. I think that Japan is lucky that this wasn't their movie, because such a crap film can only come from us here in America! Personally, i hate this movie more than anything you could possibly imagine. It's like the Devil wrote and directed it to make us suffer.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2009-05-02</date>
		<username>Omega</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Size Does Matter</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Godzilla is the 1998 remake of the old, classic and loved 1954 Japanese masterpiece, called originally Gojira, and later transliterated as Godzilla. As the original, the basic plot is pretty simple, on the model established since The Beast from 20.000 Fathoms, the first ever film to feature an "Atomic Monster"; this time, a nest of a non-identified Reptile (universally recognized as an Iguana, although there's little to no actual proof shown in the film) is accidentally shoved off with a nuclear bomb during the Experiments done upon the French Polynesia in 1995-1996, resulting in an embryo mutating into a 50 meters tall Dinosaur-Esquire Monster, that leads to the Big Apple.The new Godzilla is designed by the Tatopoulos Man himself, the one great man behind Monsters such as the Pitch Black Creatures, The Cave Mutants and the Werewolves from Underworld. No wonder, Tatopoulos did a really great job with his vision of Godzilla. He made a fresh, imposing design while respecting what made the original great. This take on Godzilla looks noble, somewhat like a Dragon (not in case since it was the intention), with all those spikes and rock-like textures. The Monster was brought to life through a mix of Computer Generated Effects, done by Centropolis, and practical Animatronics, created by Tatopoulos Studios in collaboration with KNB EFX. I still have a hard time telling which is which in some shots, especially with the new Blu-Ray release which is astounding. The primeval Beast was agile and graceful on screen. The Actors chosen as the cast are good ones, especially Hank Hazaria. Charismatic as usual Mr. Reno. Sympathetic Broderick. The whole film is a sharp piece of Entertainment, maybe the best delivered from Roland Emmerich. On the controversy... At a certain point of the film the protagonists discover that the creature has nested (it reproduces asexually) in no less than the Madison Square Garden. Totally a case, the eggs hatch right after they arrive. Being what they are, the newborns eat fish just like their parent, but seeing the people have walked on their food all along, they smell like fish and so the babies begin to chase them. This is sort of a reason to compare (thus downgrade) the little Godzillas to the Jurassic Park Velociraptors. Quite honestly, the only possible similarities can be found in the physical aspects, because the two creatures behave a whole bunch differently. While the former ones are intelligent strategists that rely on ambush to capture their prey, the latter ones are chaotic and stupid beings which just go after food and nothing else. But hey, those are newborns, what do we have to expect? Those ain't adults. Besides that, the original series did have representation of Young Godzillas - In particular it should be noted that Godzilla Vs. MechaGodzilla II features as well a Baby Godzilla the size of humans, exactly like in the remake. So, this is simply a new take on the Baby, what's the problem? The main issue most Godzilla fans have with this film is indeed that the creature is different than the original, that the anti-nuclear message with this Picture was practically flushed away, and that the monster dies. I see where they come from, but what has to be understood with this film is that this is a remake. Remake means remake, not sequel or reboot. Remake means re-conception, and this is exactly what this Godzilla is: a re-imagining of the Japanese Icon. Apparently different, but close in the heart. With recent visions I spotted some nice homages to the original films (particularily to The Return of Godzilla), along with other references to Alien, Jaws, Alligator, The Beast from 20.000 Fathoms and a bunch more film. The remake uses a similar choice to the 1986 The Fly, with the same basic plot as the original but with a brand new develop and execution. Both films are different from what they come from, but are still two fresh and innovating films. This is in fact the reason on which true remakes are made: have a different take on the subject and see how it turns out. Films like Quarantine (remake of REC) are useless because they bring nothing new to the Cinematography Mythos. Besides this, Godzilla died 2 times during his career, and bitching about him dying by 12 missiles that in a such smaller quantity blew up nothing less than the Madison Square Garden is pointless if you ask me. Regarding the origin, it's practically the same, and the anti-nuclear message is still here. In particular, Jean Reno signed on this film properly because it had an ecologist metaphor. The success of the film at the box-office, despite the tremendous fan backlash was a good thing for TOHO, since it produced a new film the year right after, called Godzilla 2000. It should be noted that in this film, Godzilla is much more reptilian and there are a lot of scenes that remind of the 1998 remake. This ain't a case I bet. Anyway, in Godzilla Final Wars, there appears a monster similar to the American Godzilla - called Zilla, because according to director Ryuhei Kitamura, the American remake "Took the God out of Godzilla" (?). This new monster however should not be confused with the American Godzilla because there are some substantial differences - it is a reference, more like a spoof, but not the same creature.I feel this movie is truly underrated. It really isn't bad - it is a classic story infused into a modern film, and because of this I feel it should be respected more. It got a lot of new fans into the franchise and made TOHO spawn yet another series of its films, not to mention the sweet Animated Series that acted as a sequel. Just see it with an open mind, and you'll enjoy it more.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>New version based on Japanese classic monster with excessive computer generator FX</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>An underwater prehistoric reptile emerges from the depths destroying ships and people . The monster terrorizes New York and its Great Apple, breaking buildings and everything to get in its ways. A researcher named Niko Tatapoulus(Mathhew Broderick)along with the army and air force commanded by a general(Kevin Dunn)track down the giant monster. Another various characters cross paths with the giant mutant, as a French agent(Jean Reno)and two reporters(Hank Azaria, Maria Pitillo).This is a roller-coaster ride plenty of action-packed, thrills,chills and breathtaking scenes. Patrick Tatopoulos design creature is well and brilliantly made. Stirring and moving musical score by David Arnold.The motion picture is middling directed by Roland Emmerich. 		<date>2008-11-16</date>
		<username>starelf-1</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fantastic movie but not Godzilla</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Probably one of the best films in the giant monster genre. The special effects are fantastic and the monster if highly believable. I fully agree with everyone here praising the movie. But I felt I needed to explain to those folks who don't understand why so many of the original fans don't like the film.By any monster movie fans standards this would be an utterly loved classic if you had given the monster any other name. Many of the fans name this monster GINO (Godzilla in Name Only) and that about sums up the real reason they hate the film. Through all the iterations and different directors in the Toho films, cheesy as they can be, Godzilla (Gojira) developed and maintained a very distinct character. He is an unstoppable force of nature to which humanity is a mere annoyance that at times he deems to help but mostly puts us in our place for overstepping our bounds.Its fairly obvious early on that the writers and director of this movie made no effort to understand or capture that character in their creation. Perhaps that can be forgiven since their stated goal was to try and create a Godzilla that moved and acted like a real giant lizard would act and they largely succeeded but in the process they totally lost the 'soul' of the original character. Their creation has a soul and personality to be sure but its just not Gojira's.I remember watching the movie in the theater for the first time with my wife during the scene with the helicopters chasing the Godzilla through the maze of buildings. I leaned over to her and said the first thing that came to my mind, "Godzilla doesn't run from helicopters" He just doesn't. He might change direction out of annoyance but not run away.I think most hard core fans will admit in private that this is a good film but publicly they just can't get over what they see is a completely wrong portrayal of a beloved character.TOHO even played off on the comparisons between this Godzilla and the original by pitting her(?)against the original in Godzilla: Final Wars in one of the most one sided, quickest defeats in the film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A monstrous mixed bag.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My Take: It's all spectacle, no thrills. The final hour is satisfying though. Rated PG-13I have to admit that back when I was a kid, I really loved watching "Godzilla", mainly because I'm a sucker for monster movies, especially dinosaur films. Another reason is that film criticism does not apply to me yet. Now that it applies, I began to see the real colors of "Godzilla", a weak and flawed film the relies too heavily on effects than plot, pacing and interest. The second half is somehow exciting, but it's the overlong and boring first half that's the problem. If you have it on DVD, you can just fast-forward it to the good parts, but trust me, the first half is darn long. So long (and boring) it almost chews up the entire running time of the film.The problem of "special-effects vs. good story" is not something new to director Roland Emmerich and co-writer/producer Dean Devlin, who made INDEPENDENCE DAY. But ID4 didn't bore me because it was fun as it is, GODZILLA on the other hand spent too much time showing us the giant lizard's feet than forming much action or human characters among them.Another thing about this film, is that it tries so hard to be another "Jurassic Park", adding, of course, the rampage of the baby Godzillas and an enjoyable final chase scene. interesting thing about the film. Obviously, it's no "Jurassic Park", and even not "The Lost World: Jurassic Park". It is, mainly, a large lizard movie that focuses more in "destroying" New York than giving audiences what they came for.I'd be lying if a say I didn't enjoy this film. It somewhat takes off on the second half, but getting there is just far too long, even for someone (or something) as big as the big "G". Rating: **1/2 out of 5.</fullReview>

		<username>weyoun790</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Godzilla the friendly lizard creature versus his Fruedian alterego</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Brilliant special effects really bring Godzilla to life in a way that far surpasses the original films and only fails to compete with the parabolic meanings behind the classic, although some grate comic performances and witty dialog make the transfer from low budget mayhap to blockbuster smash hit more bearable in a film which has been underrated by most critics.Where most misinformed critics go wrong is to project some sought of romanticised view of Godzilla as `man's best friend' and `defender of the innocent' (as if he were some 100ft tall Lassie compared to the original incarnation who tore up everthing in his path) or classify it as a farcical monster movie which is thankfully not what it is aboutin keeping faithful to the original. The black and white classic, which started the whole thing off, was trying to explore very relevant concepts before it became a ridiculous B movie franchise. It confronted a philosophical paradoxic in human nature as man is both a creative and destructive creature which is culminated in the symbol of the atom bomb in bothnfilms. The atom bomb which in the original film releases Godzilla from hibernation is the closes thing we have to witnessing the explosion, which scientists say, birthed our universe all those millions of years ago. Godzilla symbolises a part of mankind's duel nature, a repression of his psyche which had lad dormant for thousands of years and had been supposedly tamed over centuries of Enlightenment and rationalism but in fact the very thing which unleashes this creature is one of man's greatest scientific discoveries and greatest human disaster.So what is more poignant than this creature arising out of a post war Japan to as a result of man not learning from his mistakes and takes on the persona of man's self destructiveness even in the midst of peace time.For some very obvious reasons this is a story that is almost impossible to rival in terms of its parabolic significance as it was released in the wake of the events of Horroshima and Nagasaki in a climate of what in hiensight of the arms race seemed even more relevant with the MADness (Mutualy Assured Distruction) policy of the US. So what have the writers of the new film done but tried to accommodate some allegorical comment while really concentrating on a monster movie that would blow over the public. The theme of recompense is central as the creature is nature bitting back at mankind who has abused her and in the new film in a subtle plot twist [possible spoiler alert] Godzilla through asexual reproduction posses a even greater threat of replacing man as the dominant species. Where as in the originalfilm it took a new weapon that could match the atom bomb in it destructive potential but developed ironically enough by a pacifist we have a final balance of the two forces when the creature is destroyed and all trace of the new weapon which apeases this conflict in taking the life of a willing participant in the creation of new scientific wounders which manipulated to a destructive end. In the new film we do not have this reconsiliation there is a relationship built up between the creature and Broderick's character which convey the overwhelming sense of awe and respect for the creature prooving he may have understood the irony even if the writers have not. It is all culminating in the final scene with the creature outwhitted it seems it is only Broderick who has really recognised the creature for what it is.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>This is not Godzilla</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Now I saw the original classic 1954 movie "Godzilla;" "Godzilla: Final Wars;" the 2014 "Godzilla" reboot; and now I have to see this. How was it? It was not the Godzilla that everyone remembers. This is not Godzilla. Today, many people that talk about this movie will refer to the monster as "Zilla" instead of Godzilla. The monster does appears in "Godzilla: Final Wars," which it is now being part of the Godzilla universe. With that said, the movie was produced and co-written by Dean Devlin along side co-writer and director Roland Emmerich who has directed movies such as "Universal Soldiers;" "Stargate;" "The Patriot;" "The Day After Tomorrow;" "10,000 B.C.;" "2012;" and the classic popcorn entertainment "Independence Day." Emmerich has done a horrible job and he should never had directed this movie because he was not fan of any the Godzilla movies. Also, the look of the Godzilla looks nothing like the King of the Monsters that everyone loves and remembers. Oh, the CGI of God...oh, I'm sorry "Zilla" looks pretty much awful because it looks like that you would see on the Syfy channel. Although, there may be some practical effects but the CGI looks by far the worst. The story itself is horribly written, and some of the jokes don't work for example where Matthew Broderick's character looks at all fishes being putted together in a big pile, and turns to one of the soldiers and said "That's a lot of fish." How is that funny? Its not! Oh, even most of the cast that I feel sorry for are very much given a bunch of bad dialogues which makes most of the characters look stupid. I am not counting Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno because they are like the only two characters that I like, but at times might be given a bad direction. Same goes to Maria Pitillo, who is not only given a bad direction but a bad performance. However, I do feel bad for the actress, and I don't think she was that bad. Despite on what I say about giving most of the cast a bunch of bad dialogues and making characters look stupid I do say that the acting in this movie is not bad. I also don't mind the song that played during the movie's end credits "Come with Me" sung by Puff Daddy featuring Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page. Oh, I also thought spoofing Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert was very unnecessary because Emmerich did that intentionally because Siskel and Ebert never gave their movies a positive review. I know that many directors don't make movies for the critics, but they could at least just respect their opinion on a movie that they criticize on. Also, maybe just deal with criticism that whether he or she accepts it or not. I wish I can go on more about this movie, but everything else that many fans of Godzilla had already pointed out this movie on why this movie sucks. Overall, this is not Godzilla and it is not a fun popcorn entertainment as "Independence Day" was; but it is not the absolute worst movie of 1998 because I think the "Psycho" remake is the absolute worst movie of 1998, which I will review it for another time. For right now, stick with the original classic 1954 movie, and some of the other "Godzilla" movies. Even the 2014 reboot. I give this movie a 2 out of 10. Oh, and by the way, how dare they rip things off from an awesome classic Steven Spielberg movie of the 90s "Jurassic Park."</fullReview>

		<username>JAPfeif</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Definitely NOT a bad movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I was all set to write a review on the movie defending it from all the negative flack it gets and I admittedly assumed that when I logged on here all I would see were negative comments. Actually, I scrolled through two pages and found not one negative review, all positives, so I guess no defending is necessary! So I just want to add that this movie in NO WAY deserves all the criticism it gets. I am an avid fan of the original Godzilla series and have a subscription to G-Fan, so I totally appreciate most of J.D. Lees's comments and opinions. I just do not get the backlash against this movie, except for probably ONE reason. The name.I think most folks were expecting basically a remake of the original Godzilla, same look, same mannerisms, same often-times hokey behavior, and when they didn't get that, they complain and moan. I agree with a previous poster here....if Roland et. al. HAD done that, made a creature that was just like the original in THIS day and age, the movie really WOULD have gotten lambasted and shot down. Besides, they already TRIED that once, remember? (anyone recall GODZILLA 1985??.....practically a carbon-copy of the look of the original monster and if I recall, it wasn't exactly a blockbuster!). So the film makers tried something new, totally updated effects (and no one can deny that they were excellent), an interesting plot, a new twist on the original, a cast of likable characters...and it gets totally ripped apart.Which brings me to my original point I wanted to make. The name. I honestly believe that if the film (and monster) had NOT been called "Godzilla", just called "Monstersaurus" or something, and not been made to appear as the iconic monster from our childhood, the movie would have done great in more people's eyes (well, at least on the level as other similarly-themed films like INDEPENDENCE DAY, TWISTER, and such). The kiss of death for many people was that they felt the movie was trying to "pass off" this monster as "Godzilla". And they didn't like that.......they didn't like the idea of totally changing the look and actions of a very iconic pop culture figure.So yeah.....had the movie been called something else and not associated with Godzilla in any way, I think the outcome would have been way different. Because, there sure wasn't much else to complain about in this movie! It was great!! Just my two pennies!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-04-14</date>
		<username>Paul Andrews (poolandrews@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>"What is this? The virgin lizard?" I loved it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Godzilla starts as a Japanese cannery ship is attacked by something massive from the depths of the Ocean, the following day a Japanese crew-member talks of 'Gojira'... US atomic energy commission biologist Niko Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) is an expert on radiation mutated lifeforms &amp; is asked by the US military to assist them on a case where a giant footprint has been discovered, a footprint that couldn't have been made by any known living creature. Shortly after a giant lizard tramples his way through Manhattan causing death &amp; destruction as he trashes the place. Tatopoulos &amp; the military headed up by Colonel Hicks (Kevin Dunn) are hot on it's tail &amp; are determined to destroy it although that proves harder than first thought as Gojira is fast, strong, aggressive &amp; very intelligent. Meanwhile Niko's ex girlfriend news reporter Audrey Timmonds (Maria Pitillo) sense she can get inside information on Gojira, which ends up being mispronounced by the American media as Godzilla, this gets Niko into trouble, taken off the team &amp; discredited even though he thinks that Godzilla may have laid eggs which will hatch soon, overrun the city &amp; eventually the world...Co-written, co-executive produced &amp; directed by Roland Emmerich I have to say right now that I loved Godzilla &amp; for that I make no apology whatsoever. Obviously based on the creaky old Japanese Toho series that featured Godzilla this big budget American take on things has NOTHING to do with them at all apart from the Godzilla name which is more than fine with me. Everyone who dislikes this Godzilla seem to 'fondly' remember the originals but I firmly believe that they are really overrated, the special effects are pathetic, the English dialogue &amp; dubbing are unintentionally hilarious &amp; I think most people these days would have a hard time liking them &amp; I also believe that people say they like them because they probably have good childhood memories of them. Anyway, I thought this Godzilla was everything that I want to see in a monster film, it moves along like a rocket, it's never dull or boring &amp; delivers some of the best popcorn entertainment I've ever seen. The special effects are spectacular even today, there isn't much of a story but again I remind you that the Japanese Godzillas didn't either, the character's are likable even the comedy relief Mayor &amp; his sidekick, you can actually understand the dialogue &amp; the film just provides wonderful monster sized fun! Was I the only one who felt just a teeny weeny bit sad at Godzillas death? Call me a softie but I liked the big fella &amp; felt sorry for the guy when he never actually deliberately set out to kill or even hurt anyone, he was just doing what came naturally. On the negative side I felt it went on for a bit too long &amp; I just couldn't get past the fact that someone could lose a gigantic monster in New York, it's not like someone might not notice it walking down the street, is it? I mean it's big enough for someone not to lose it.Director Emmerich gives his audience a brilliant &amp; exhilarating roller-coaster ride of thrilling set pieces from helicopter gunship chases, a fantastic taxi cab chase through the streets of Manhattan, explosions, underwater sequences, dozens of baby Godzillas running around Madison Square Garden, a great ending scene set on a suspension bridge &amp; some cool shots of Godzilla trampling his way through the streets of New York. The film has a certain gloomy atmosphere as it is always raining, in fact 2.4 million gallons of water was used for the rain during filming. That's a lot of water.With a supposed budget of about ?125,000,000 this had a massive budget which shows, the special effects are brilliant &amp; are still among the best ever put on film. I love the new Godzilla design even though many didn't. One thing I must add is that I hated the soundtrack, I found it totally inappropriate &amp; just didn't suit the on screen action at all, it seemed more suited for a romantic film, very strange. The acting was OK, Pitillo was cute, Jean Reno was cool &amp; Simpsons fans will spot voice regulars Hank Azaria, Harry Shearer &amp; Nancy Cartwright here.A lot of people hate this film which is fine, I really couldn't care less what other's think because films are all about personal opinion &amp; my opinion of Godzilla is that I loved it &amp; thought it was everything I wanted it to be. I can't recommend it as so many people seem to dislike it &amp; I appear to be in the minority, I still think it's brilliant though, it's as simple &amp; straight forward as that.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>MacShark</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful B Movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Godzilla is a giant, nuclear mutated lizard. With that, how could anyone possibly take it seriously? This goes for the "old" Godzilla (a giant, nuclear mutated extinct dinosaur) as well.I have loved the "old" Godzilla movies since I was 7 and in all honesty, they are terrible. The acting doesn't even make it up to the level of "poor." The effects are laughable at best. But what they are is fun. This is the same as the "new" Godzilla. This time there is no man in a big rubber suit. The monster looks just plain good. And at least there is some sort of reason for it running through NYC instead of it crashing through a city because it's in a foul mood. The reason may be full of holes (why NYC, Tokyo is closer. How'd it KNOW about cities in the first place?), but at least there's a reason.All of the negative things that have been said about this movie thus far have been some of the things the older versions had been praised for. And while there are obvious rip-offs of other movies, remember these are the same makers of Independence Day, a film that didn't have one original idea, but is a collection of other science fiction movies. This is apparently the producer's method of making movies. People can see this as ripping off -- negative -- or see it as an homage to other great films -- positive.I'll buy this movie. I'll sit and watch it over and over again. I'll laugh at all the rotten parts. I'll have fun doing it. Sometimes that's the whole point of watching movies.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2012-09-23</date>
		<username>gizmomogwai</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>America butchers Godzilla once again</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The 1954 Japanese classic film Godzilla is very good as a horror film and a fun movie, which was thankfully recently given Criterion treatment. Alas, in the West the film has not always been available in its true form. In 1956 it was butchered thoroughly, massively edited and manipulated into Godzilla, King of the Monsters!, a goofy movie in badly dubbed English. If that weren't enough, in 1998 the Americans decided to butcher Godzilla again, with a movie about as bad- Godzilla, by the makers of the smash hit Independence Day (1996).Because of my love of Independence Day as a youth, when I saw Godzilla '98 in theatres I assumed I had to like it, and tried to convince myself it was a good movie, much as with Batman and Robin the year before. Time has made me realize how much of that was self-deception, however. Godzilla '98 is loud and often stupid, and the action scenes never really blew me away. Most of the damage to New York City in the film is done not by Godzilla but by the army trying to kill the creature. The moments of comic relief all fall flat (we were supposed to be rolling over laughing every time someone called Broderick "the worm guy"). The movie repeatedly pulls the same tricks, with people thinking they're clear of danger before Godzilla pops up suddenly again. The dialogue is often painful, as adult characters interact as if they were children ("You were supposed to be my friend, I trusted you.")Some parts defy logic. Why can't the military ever actually shoot Godzilla? Are we really supposed to believe Godzilla can pick up a car in his mouth and crunch on it but the car and people inside it are still functioning? The Nostalgia Critic also did a good job illustrating how the "Babyzilla" scenes imitate the raptor scenes in Jurassic Park (1993). Admittedly, I still love this movie's soundtrack. "Macy Day Parade" by Michael Penn and "Untitled" by Silverchair are beautiful songs, though unfortunately they don't seem to be in the film itself, which favours "Come With Me" by Puff Daddy which is only sort of okay because it sounds like "Kashmir." The special effects are mostly good, although we don't actually get a good look at Godzilla besides his feet. The movie also had an attractive ad campaign. One commercial showed Godzilla stepping on and destroying a tyrannosaur fossil, and that unfortunately isn't in the movie either. Ultimately, Godzilla '98 has none of the charm of the Japanese original, and is more of a cliché Hollywood disaster movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2010-02-28</date>
		<username>TravelingExecutioner</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Night of the Iguana</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Wesconnosehny wrote one of the shortest, funniest reviews of this movie.I'm a huge monster/sci-fi fan, but after seeing 'Godzilla' in a theater on opening day, I felt oddly ambivalent. I didn't hate the movie, neither did I fall in love with it. The film was okay, but nothing special. As with 'Independence Day' and '2012,' 'Godzilla' was crammed with tankerloads of expertly-rendered CG imagery, but the film had very little magic, or heart (or soul). It didn't fire my imagination the way I expected it to. It didn't inspire the sense of awe I was looking for. Godzilla him(her?)self just looked like a bigger version of the pet iguana I used to have--nothing remarkable there--and the human characters were so flat and forgettable, it was hard to care what happened to any of them. A couple of lines of pithy dialogue don't make for engaging characters. It wasn't the fake-looking rubber shark that made 'Jaws' such a success (the special effects weren't that great), it was the script and the characters--things that had nothing to do with special effects.I read that Roland Emmerich insisted on having Godzilla be able to run really fast. Which, again, would be very accurate if Godzilla were an iguana. But to me, one of Godzilla's most compelling qualities is that he is ostensibly so massive and powerful, he's not afraid of anything and doesn't have to run from anybody. If Emmerich wants to push the 'realism' issue--which is a mistake--I would argue that no reptile, no matter how big or fast, would be able to survive or outmaneuver a squad of F-14 fighter jets. (The conundrum, of course, is that the bigger Godzilla is, the harder it would be for him to outmaneuver them.) 'Jurassic Park' set the CG bar pretty high. Since then, CG effects have become so polished and prolific (and overused?) that they're a dime a dozen. They've lost their 'wow' factor. (Except for 'Avatar' maybe.) Perhaps I've seen so many fantasy/sci-fi movies that I've gotten a little jaded, but it takes more than just a few ingenious digital effects to impress me these days. During the fighter-jet chase through the maze of Manhattan skyscrapers, I felt less like I was watching a movie than a giant first-person shooter game. If I'd wanted that, I'd have played with an X-box. (At least I'd have had the fun of doing some of the shooting.) I wasn't disappointed with 'Godzilla' because it was all that bad, but because it just wasn't all that good.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>When a ship is attacked at sea by an monster that is suspected to have a politically damaging source of origin, Matthew Broderick is called in as an expert in the effects of radiation on lifeforms.From the start Jean Reno, an insurance investigator is hot on the tail of Broderick and the creature to get some answers of his own.Now Matthew Broderick has a great knack of appearing in bad films and delivering poor performances (e.g. Inspector Gadget, The Cable Guy) where Jean Reno is pretty much the opposite (e.g. Leon, Ronin) Thank god when Reno appears in a film that is - Shall we say, less intelligent and full of cheese, he can still deliver an believable and serious performance.In Godzilla it is quite literally only Reno and the special effects team that emerge with the credit of hauling this film out from the depths it seemed so desperate to reach.Anyway, that's enough of bashing this movie - What about the good points? 		<date>2016-09-10</date>
		<username>metalrage666</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A large pile of stinking fish sums this up perfectly</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, despite all the money that this movie somehow made, this is pure garbage from start to finish. The story is as non existent as much as the acting. In retrospect almost everyone ever involved with this now regrets the final product. There's no point in me summarising the plot as it's been done and there isn't much of a plot anyway but I wanted to at least weigh in on why this is so abysmal. I've watched this several times and each time I'm left scratching my head over what the hell is everybody doing. It struggles to be funny with several running gags throughout the movie but they all come off as being lame attempts at cheap laughs. Like bad dad jokes they just get more and more annoying as the movie digs its own grave while trying to generate a laugh. I was never sure which was worse, the various cast constantly mispronouncing the name Tatopoulos or the head of the French secret service trying and failing to get a decent cup of coffee. There was just so much in this that never made any sense and the whole thing seems to be an exposition in how not to make a movie. I could never work out why the U.S ground forces in and around New York were all controlled by a bungling and inept Sergeant of all things; I'd expect a Lieutenant or Captain at least. Why would a worm scientist be the go-to guy for a reptile? Why not a reptile specialist? If you're in a helicopter and Godzila is chasing you, why fly straight? Why not go up? Why can't the French secret service speak English properly? Why do an Elvis impersonation under the guise that all Americans speak that way? And why would that fool anyone? How does a giant lizard manage to make it all the way to Manhattan, creating mass devastation along the way and not have the story leaked to any number of media outlets? If the tape of the first sighting was so security sensitive why was it left unsecured and in the hands of a civilian so anyone could get at it? Why would an animal as large as Godzilla assume that NYC, one of the most densely populated islands, is the best place to spawn after it's been relentlessly attacked since it got there and it's an unnatural environment? How would a lizard, regardless of size, know what a submarine is or how to destroy one using their own torpedoes? When the baby Godzillas are roaming around, why are they seen eating popcorn when their diet is mostly fish? The French guy is the one who's driving the taxi during a crisis and knows how to get to the Brooklyn Bridge! What's worse is that Godzilla also somehow knows where the Brooklyn Bridge is, manages to get there first and pops up in the right spot in order to cut them off! And it goes on and on like this and it never redeems itself until the credits start to roll. I can accept a big dumb monster movie but I'd still prefer it to showcase some kind of logic and have a plot worth following. I think everyone in this was miscast and for me that made the movie even more painful to watch. The combination of Godzilla destroying every building it touched or grazed against coupled with the whiz-bang U.S military gleefully destroying everything else, makes for good special effects but does little for common sense. This didn't have any of the essence of what gave Godzilla such a dedicated fan base in the first place and highlights that Hollywood directors should leave well enough alone if they're not going to be bothered with doing justice to an iconic character. It's little wonder they never ended up doing a sequel, it would've been like trying to remove glue from hair after this colossal debacle.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>classicsoncall</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>"That's a lot of fish".</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought the movie was OK when it first came out and thought the same after watching it again a little while ago. Funny how you can't please some folks; the picture took it's fair share of hits by the fan-boys who slammed it for one reason or another back in the day. As a dinosaur loving kid growing up in the Fifties I got hooked on these flicks with the original 1954 "Godzilla", or "Gojira" if you will going with the Japanese translation.Watching today however brings an entirely new perspective to the story. The first view one has of the Manhattan skyline with a clear image of the Twin Towers only three years before it was brought down by terrorists got a sobering response from this viewer. The destruction wrought by the monster on the streets of New York was in it's own way oddly prescient of the calamity brought to bear on the city on 9/11. One of the characters even references the 1993 World Trade Center bombing to bring that arc full circle.I recall thinking at the time of the movie's release that Matthew Broderick was the wrong choice to play the lead here, but once again, time has mellowed out my reaction to that. He did a credible job along with the supporting cast, and the minor twist with Jean Reno's character was handled cleverly. What I had a little trouble processing though was how a lot of the characters in the story had a tough time making a phone call a mere eighteen years ago, when today the ubiquitous presence of cell phones makes it possible to communicate at a second's notice. Not to mention citizen journalists posting videos on youtube; it really makes you think.In deference to the film's critics, I do realize there was some extraordinarily goofy stuff going on in the picture along with the mayhem. Gunning the taxi out of the mouth of the resurrected Godzilla was a stretch by anyone's estimation, but hey, when it comes to monsters, action and big guns, I guess anything is to be expected. Even if you have to blow up Madison Square Garden to save the day.</fullReview>

		<date>2015-04-26</date>
		<username>Taylor Kingston</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A fantastic movie...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't understand why so many people think this movie is terrible. I love it. Granted it is a big difference from the original Godzilla legend, but still. It's not meant to be that realistic anyway. I love this movie, I really do. It's funny and I love Matthew Broderick. This movie is about Godzilla. A big lizard, basically. After atomic bomb tests in the South Pacific, Godzilla makes it's way through the Panama Canal. They call a scientist in, Niko Tatopolous, to help investigate what the creature is. They figure that the giant lizard was created by the atomic bomb testing. Who knew? Godzilla makes its way to New York City where he destroys the city. Everyone, including the combined U.S. military, must come together to try and figure out a way to eliminate the unusually large reptile.Overall, I give this movie a 7 out of 10: Great.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2015-03-29</date>
		<username>Ruairidh MacVeigh</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Not as bad as you might think</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I will be honest, this is a silly movie, especially when the story revolves around a 400ft high mutant lizard roaming the streets of Manhattan, but to be honest I consider this film one of the truest forms of guilty pleasures, largely because it's a perfect disengage- brain film.What's the chestnut? Following nuclear tests on islands in the Pacific by the French, a lizard egg doused in radiation mutates into the giant monster known as Godzilla, which starts attacking fish carrying cargo ships, runs a rampage across Panama, before arriving in New York City, where pursuing scientist Niko Tatopoulos believes that the creature is planning to create a nest and give birth asexually to even more of these reptilian monstrosities.Indeed critics and fans alike decimated this movie upon release, calling it just a mindless orgy of violence and explosions with no logical story or interesting characters to back it up, and they may have had a point there. It really is a silly film, with the aforementioned explosions and violence, and the fact that there are enough holes in the plot to sink the Grand Atlantic Fleet. The characters are also fairly dull, with no discernible features about them apart from the generic traits of nerdy scientist, cold and calm secret agent, typical RomCom love interest and relationship with such, etc.But if I'm brutally, brutally honest, if you want an action film with a simple A &gt; B plot that revolves around just defeating a gigantic monster in the city of New York, with all the violence and explosions as standard, then this is the film for you. It's not a film that requires the slightest semblance of thought, but as a film you can switch your mind off too and simply watch the action unfold, it's really not that bad. I certainly enjoy it, and I do get quite invested, with CGI that in places is a bit ropey but on the whole not that bad to help me along.To summarize, I'd recommend this film to people who just want a standard action movie to take 2 hours out of their rainy Saturday afternoon, as for those who desire a film with a bit more thought and logical sense, this is not it.</fullReview>
	</review>

Its very silly.But that is what makes it great! Its not trying to be identical to Japanese Godzilla. This one isn't a laser beam breath GOD! It is simply a animal trying to find a place to nurture it's offspring. The people in the city will serve as snack for the kids!The actors are aware their roles are silly and it shows. Only a couple of them had poor acting. They are all slightly silly and goofy and even likable and memorable.Godzilla is pretty likable himself! Hes not going after humans as a food source. He eats fish! And lots of fish! If you get under his feet...well that's a shame but he wont target you(unless you murder his children!). He can take damage, he flees and fights for his life. He mourns and wants revenge for his lost children and walks in a trap doing so.All in all. Its a silly movie with quite a bit of action and you get to see the monster a lot! unlike most of todays movies. Just don't turn it on and expect a movie with great plot and similarities to the Japanese Godzilla.</fullReview>

I can't say the same for Maria Pitillo though -- the role seemed to be perfect for Sarah Jessica Parker, but I don't think any actress could have saved this nasty little creature. It's best we ignore her and focus on the true comedic genius in this film -- Hank Azaria.The plot is a little weak admittedly in its use of "scientific facts", but come on -- "Independence Day" pulled some pretty big mess-ups too. For sheer comedic value, this is an excellent movie to watch, although it does lose some of the effects if watched on the television -- this movie should be watched for the first time on the big screen. For excellence of comedy, hilarious actors (including the shiver-in-his-boots soldier, played by Doug Savant), and basic on-the-edge-of-your-seat fun, I give this movie a 9 out of 10!</fullReview>

		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great entertainment!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Finally a disaster movie that is not a disaster itself! This is the most fun I have had in a cinema since the Fifth Element. The makers of the film have been consistent in their approach, they have gone for an entertaining film with LOTS of special effects and they don't take themselves seriously for a second. This is where the strength of this film lies. Many critics have complained about cardboard characters and no originality, well in my view, that's the whole point! This is made as a FUN movie, the thousands of clichés are there quite intentionally. It is the action and Godzilla himself that "carrie" the movie. If you tried going for character development in this film, you would get a ridiculous clash of styles. In a film where a several hundred feet tall lizard is attacking New York, any attempts at seriousness at any point would just be out of place and ridiculous (Armageddon springs to mind). As a European, it is also nice to see for once an American disaster movie without any of the sickening quasi-patriotism that so plagued films like ID4, Deep Impact and Armageddon. Emmerich is improving with every movie he makes.</fullReview>

		<username>Gregory Zerwekh (gzerwekh@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Letter of disgust sent to Columbia/Tristar.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The following is a copy of a letter I wrote to Columbia/Tristar regarding Godzilla. I have yet to receive even a simple form letter in reply.Columbia Pictures Corporation 10202 Washington Boulevard Culver City, CA 90232 (310) 280-8000Attn: Consumer Relations Department Re: Godzilla To: Dean Devlin, Roland Emmerich, Columbia/Tristar Producers &amp; Executives, et. al.Have you all lost your minds? Has the moving making fire really gone out of your souls? Are you so motivated by merchandising tie-ins and opening weekend grosses that you have forgotten how to make even a mediocre film ?A little over a week ago, my brother and I went to see Godzilla. I had prepared myself to be less than overwhelmed after reading several scathing reviews. But hey, these were the same guys that made "Independence Day" and "Stargate," so how bad could it be? I wasn't, however, prepared for such a dismal, depressing example of all that is wrong with movie making today.Honestly, did any of you actually read the script before going forward? Did you think the running gag involving "Gene" and "Ebert" was actually funny? Or that you were being clever by having everyone in the movie mispronounce Matthew Broderick's character's name. Every one of your characters were flat, uncompelling. I found myself cringing during the "quiet" moments that you apparently thought would give these people depth. My brother actually put his head between his knees to stifle his snickers.Those quiet moments, however, were almost preferable to your hackneyed portrayal of the military. Why do filmmakers find it necessary to present us with unflattering portrayals of our Armed Forces as well as wholly ignorant depictions of military weaponry and procedures? You two have made films with military themes in the past, so I know that you know how to get at least half right. But please, two missiles will not cut the Chrysler building in half, nor will a couple of rockets obliterate Madison Square Garden. Furthermore, an emotional wreck of a sergeant would not be put in operational command of ditch digging let alone the destruction of a radioactive mutant crocodile. Did you even bother to hire a military advisor? Did you listen to him?I've never written a letter like this before, but I just wanted you to know that you took what could have been an exciting story, gave it a GREAT ad campaign, and failed to deliver something even remotely interesting. Given a reported budget of $100 MM, one would think you could have afforded to hire the extra talent required to make a good film. Apparently this is no longer one of your priorities.Cheers!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>1998-09-12</date>
		<username>Sabrina Dziardziel</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Needs improvement, but a good first try.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'd like to consider myself a devoted fan of Godzilla, as I love the classic movies. While this new one falls short of deserving such revere, I do believe all the negative reviews are uncalled for. True, some of the casting left a lot to be desired (Pitillo and Broderick come to mind). But this Godzilla movie does something that NONE of the classic one did. It shows Godzilla as a creature, not a monster bent on creating havoc. As with all creature-features it's only natural to root for the decline of humanity at the claws of nature's creation. But here we're shown two creatures, humans and Godzilla, how are striving to survive. Humans attack Godzilla because he's (or she's) destroying our homes and businesses. Godzilla only attacks out of self defense, and later out of revenge over the death of its young. Aside from the National Geographic aspects, the special effects deserve an Oscar nomination, if not Oscar himself. Godzilla looked and behaved in a believable manner. Not since Jurassic Park has this occurred. One final note, for a 'pitiful, weak story' GODZILLA is in the top-five take of 1998's summer grosses. Roland and Dean, if you do a sequel as planned, really reconsider casting.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>1998-08-17</date>
		<username>Andrew Duff (andrew@asi-uk.com)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Living proof that hype can kill.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went into this movie with fairly low expectations, having endured a year of hype followed by 2 months of bad press. Although it was by no means good, it was nowhere near as bad as I expected. The flaws, though huge, should have been obvious and easy to fix : total lack of suspense buildup in the beginning, some truly awful dialogue (Matthew Broderick isn't a bad actor but anyone seeing him here for the first time would think he was retarded), Maria Pitillo, and the fact that Godzilla is cast as a victim rather than a menace. So instead of feeling like the good guys kicked butt and killed the evil monster, you feel like the good guys weren't so good and killed a big, but essentially harmless creature. During the best scene in the movie (the helicopter chase) I was cheering for Godzilla! Broderick's character was a problem - his feelings about Godzilla were never clear and he was far too wimpy to be the hero. Ultimately the movie is (just) saved from being a total waste of time by star turns from Jean Reno and Hank Azaria, and by some great special effects and action set-pieces. It did manage to hold my interest through all 140 minutes. But with just a little more time spent on the script it could have been so much better.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Hinopio</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>If size matters, this was a huge disappointment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was a very large disappointment. First of all Matthew Broderick was not a good choice for the role of Niko Tau.. whatever. He is much more suited for roles in movies like Ferris Bueller and Addicted to Love than an action hero. I also felt that he wasn't motivated to make this a memorable role for him. (Watch his facial expression and hear his voice when he discovers his tape has been stolen.) As long as we're talking about the tape, why did they want to keep Godzilla's origin a secret anyway ? They should have been more concerned about the lizard itself. The Audrey character was terrible too, and was there merely for T&amp;A. The only two people who showed any real emotion in their roles were Hank Azaria and Phillipe Bergeren. Unfortunately they were under-used and the two of them should have easily been the best choices for the main characters , because we could have done without the "lovers reunited" subplot. Our hero has been shrunk from his Tokyo kin, and now instead of a rubber suit is a CGI character. I didn't really think he looked all that bad, compared to a real iguana anyway. The human characters trying to stop him caused much more damage then the lizard itself, and they should have tried other strategies than simply "point and shoot." At the end of the movie the writers try to make us feel sorry for the creature by showing us that it was "just doing what nature intended it to do" but it just doesn't work. A sequel probably will be made, and if it does I hope that there are new characters and writers, and most importantly, I hope they bring in another giant creature for Godzilla to duke it out with. This is one of those movies where you should just wait until it comes out on HBO instead of paying to see it.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2015-08-12</date>
		<username>CinemaClown</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Guilty Pleasure Is A Guilty Pleasure!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's a good thing that I watched this movie back when I was just another stupid kid who had no idea that this monster was a Japanese creation plus actually ended up enjoying it a lot &amp; used to rewatch it whenever it aired on TV. Looking back now, it's nearly impossible to ignore the countless shortcomings but blame it on nostalgia, it still remains a guilty pleasure.Reimagining the legendary monster of Japanese cinema in Hollywood style, Godzilla tells the story of its titular character; a giant irradiated lizard that travels to Manhattan in search of a new home and wrecks havoc all over the city. As the US military tries to deal with this new monster, a scientist, a mysterious French guy, an aspiring journalist &amp; her cameraman conduct their own investigation.Co-written &amp; directed by Roland Emmerich who simply has a knack for insulting the human intelligence with his illogical, nonsensical &amp; insipid features, Godzilla is no exception from his other works in the disaster genre for it completely slaughters the legacy of the monster, is so ridiculous that it's laughable for the most part, is filled with truly annoying characters, and yet has a quite enjoyable side to it.The direction is pure Emmerich, screenplay is terribly written, New York City never gets one moment of sunshine, visual effects looks badly dated, Godzilla's design is still quite impressive even if it doesn't share any resemblance with the original beast, camera-work isn't that bad, editing provides a fine pace, David Arnold's score is pretty good, and the performances by the cast is lame for the characters they play are dull &amp; soulless.On an overall scale, Godzilla is an absolute atrocity from a storyline perspective for it ends up making a complete mockery of its subject matter and is going to be a painful sit for any fan of the original franchise. A dumb motion picture filled with towering set pieces &amp; hollow characters that throws in one lifeless sequence after another from start to finish, Godzilla is a disaster of epic proportions but it doesn't mean that you can't have fun watching it. A guilty pleasure is a guilty pleasure after all!</fullReview>
	</review>
