		<username>parhat</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Godzilla in Name Only</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie would vastly improved if they don't name this movie Godzilla. They can call the movie Mutations, or some other names. So the name really hurt the movie. As a movie goer, you will expect certain fidelity of the original Godzilla.This is true whether you talk of the movie Superman, Spiderman, Batman, or any other movie that is a remake. The movie is remake from a popular series because there was something people like about the character which absolutely had nothing to do with the name. The big name will buy you box office in the first couple of days, after a week it is downhill. If the director and producer would get the idea that a remake is not reinvent. Also Dean Devlin completely forgot people watch the movies not for special effects, they come for the movie because of their strong identification with the character of the movie.For original Godzilla, people love the stupid dumb bumbling beasts who are indestructible from man's own sins and he is punished. That is basically the psychological attachment we have with the character. The feeling of pity we have for the monster, much like Hunchback of Notre Dame, or the Beauty and the Beast, well, you get the idea. The concept and character of this beast is within the bounds of a classic story while the movie Godzilla (1998) had none of those classic story identification. It is very close to a cheap copy of other movies from George Pal's movies and other similar American made movie without any character identification. As a professional screenwriter the most important factor in a successful writing is the strong identification of character where the audiences strongly identifies with his thinking, philosophy or other things. If there is none, then it is just nothing but a fantastic mindless SFX movie without any cult following.Cult following needs a certain element of identification, Star Trek (utopia), Time Tunnel (be part of an important events), Matrix (choice of reality), Casablanca (personal bitterness versus greater good), Dr. Strangelove (the inevitably of destruction), and Godzilla (man's sin will be punished). All these hidden meanings not mentioned in the movie is what gives movie its magic. Take for example Godfather, there was absolutely no mention of the word mafia, and the writer and the director made sure of that fact. Because these concepts lurks in our darkest corners, the psyche is very powerful.If you WANT to enjoy the film rename this movie or put in a new label and call it "Jurassic Park 6" and you will find it tolerable to watch, and enjoy the movie. If you have not watched original godzilla before, then this is good news, because this is a blockbuster movie. Don't make any references to original movie though, it is an American monster movie, has absolutely nothing to do with Japanese monster movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2005-09-06</date>
		<username>Jackson Booth-Millard</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Godzilla</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>From Razzie nominated director Roland Emmerich (Independence Day, The Day After Tomorrow, 10,000 BC), when I was younger I used to quite like this film, a remake of the famous Japanese original, but I had to see it again in my older age to get a definite opinion. Basically French nuclear tests have been going on in the Pacific Ocean, and it was observed by marine iguanas, so obviously the radiation has fused with one of these lizards to create a monster that first attacks Japan. Dr. Niko 'Nick' Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) is investigating a giant footprint found on the border of New York City, and soon enough this large dinosaur like creature, Godzilla, rages through the skyscrapers to terrorise the people. They know that Godzilla is fulfilling some kind of need, so they decide to lure the monster back and plan their attack to pile a mountain of fish in the middle of a road, and then fire at the creature, but this plan doesn't work very well. Nick comes to the conclusion that Godzilla is asexual, which means that he/she will give birth to other babies that will also be pregnant and reproduce rapidly, but they supposedly manage to kill Godzilla on its way back to the ocean. Nick, French Secret Service agent Philippe Roaché (Jean Reno), Nick's ex-girlfriend and aspiring journalist Audrey Timmonds (Razzie winning Maria Pitillo) and cameraman Victor 'Animal' Palotti (The Simpsons' Hank Azaria) manage to find the nest in Madison Square Garden. The hundreds of eggs hatch and the baby Godzilla chase them, as they smell of fish, so they rush upstairs and try to get away from the creatures, and they manage to find a news casting room to give out a warning. The armed forces send out bomber planes to destroy the building, and all the babies are killed in the wreckage, but then all of the sudden Godzilla crashes through the floor and has returned, and it wants revenge for the death of her offspring. While trapped in a tunnel, Nick works out a way to possibly get the opportunity to attack Godzilla, by trapping the monster in a suspension bridge, so they head for Brooklyn Bridge, and it does indeed end up trapped in the suspension cables. It ends with Godzilla attacked by missiles and killed, Nick and Audrey possibly back together, and Roaché disappearing with Animal's camera footage of the monsters, but of course it returns to the wreckage of Madison Square Garden, where one egg remains and hatches. Also starring Small Soldiers' Kevin Dunn as Colonel Hicks, Michael Lerner as Mayor Ebert, The Simpsons' Harry Shearer as Charles Caiman, Arabella Field as Lucy Palotti, Vicki Lewis as Dr. Elsie Chapman, Doug Savant as Sergeant O'Neal, Malcolm Danare as Dr. Mendel Craven and Lorry Goldman as Gene - Mayor's Aide. The cast are I guess fine, but it is obvious most attention is drawn to the monster, using some pretty alright special effects to create the roaring beast and the buildings being destroyed, I think the most memorable sequence is the characters chased in the building by the babies. I can see however why the critics give it two stars out of five, it is not all that scary or thrilling like the original version, and it does at times feel very cheesy, but if you do like an easy watch with some fun action and a fair amount of destruction then I guess this isn't terrible, a sometimes dreary but relatively alright monster horror disaster movie. It won the Razzie for Worst Remake or Sequel, and it was nominated for Worst Picture and Worst Screenplay. Okay!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>First off I would like to point out that I have only seen the original Godzilla movie and therefore would not really call myself a fan of the whole Godzilla franchise. Roland Emmerich. Now I have to admit first, that I did enjoy Patriot and it does not follow the exact same formula that Emmerich does with all of his movies, so don't apply the following to the Patriot. Stargate, Indepedence Day, Godzilla, and probably Day after Tomorrow (haven't seen it yet but from the trailers looks the same) all follow the same action/adventure/sci-fi formula created by Mr. Steven Spielberg. Clear sense of who the good guys are and who the bad guys are; storyline centers around action that needs lots of special effects; corny, campy (and in Emmerich's case not funny) jokes; action sequences that are exciting but not too intense, so that young kids can watch; and a light-hearted fun adventure movie that is supposed to leave you with a good warm feeling by the end.Unfortunately for Emmerich, he fails in every aspect of this formula that Spielberg created. And his attempts come off as very superficial. The characters have no depth. The story lines are EXTREMELY predictable, overly simplistic, and because everything feels like a rip-off (unless you have never seen a Spielberg film), leaves you feeling bored, your intelligence insulted, and just wanting to leave, turn it off and go and rent Indiana Jones.This was my all-time worst movie I had ever seen, until I saw Battlefield Earth. Please avoid at all costs!</fullReview>

		<date>2004-05-01</date>
		<username>lacking_activity</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>good clean fun</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why is there something so monumentally cool about a gigantic radioactive lizard smashing apart Manhattan?Frankly, I do like this film a lot. Sure, it doesn't rate high on my list of all-time greats, but it is one of those films I keep coming back to at least once a year.So what makes it so good? I've seen the Japanese "rubber suit" versions, and I've compared them to this. Really, this is a whole different beast. Leaner, smarter, faster, more vulnerable, the Godzilla of this film is very different to the Japanese "Gojira". In many ways, the name is the only real similarity between the films. on the one hand, you have this world-threatening monster, and on the other hand you have this confused animal being hounded through the streets of New York for reasons it can't possibly fathom.You can feel more for this Godzilla. When the japanese rubber version was finally defeated, you always got the impression of a monster having been rightly stopped. It felt like a good and heroic event.In this film, however, we have a character, as opposed to some brainless engine of destruction. Godzilla has believable motives, such as reproduction, revenge, and self-defense. Was it ever satisfactorily explained why Gojira was always on the rampage? When the end of the movie comes, and Godzilla's lying in the street, mewling as it dies slowly, we're left feeling sorry for it. I say well done, Hollywood, for giving us a film that makes us the death of a building-sized monster.On a technical note, I still very much like the way the creature was done. A lot of work went into modelling and animating that thing, and it very much stands up to scrutiny today. Gojira never moved like a lizard, it always looked big, clumsy and stompy. Godzilla really puts us in mind of a lean, muscular, predatory reptile, like an enormous alligator. It moves with the kind of agility and grace that all real animals have, and that sense of sleek, if monstrously large, death gives Godzilla a much more menacing air than Gojira ever had.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2004-03-20</date>
		<username>dr_foreman</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>attack of the ugly Americans</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Most Americans have only been exposed to heavily edited, badly dubbed versions of the old Godzilla films, and they judge these films to be poor based on incomplete information. In the original Japanese, with more serious acting, the oft-derided Toho movies are actually quite good, if you can tolerate foreign special effects that are more imaginative than convincing. This movie, on the other hand, is a dog in any language. The first Japanese Godzilla film is an exploration of the atomic threat; Godzilla is not so much a monster as he is a walking symbol of the nuclear bomb. In this film, radiation does play a part in mutating Godzilla into a giant, stooped-over and ludicrous-looking iguana, but the "cautionary tale" aspect of the original concept is lost. Godzilla is supposed to be a condemnation of America's use of the bomb, but in this film, we pawn off the blame for Godzilla's creation on the French - how lame is that?Ridiculous attempts have been made to make the creature more "realistic." It reproduces (just so we can have a "Jurassic Park" ripoff sequence involving raptor-like babies), it doesn't breathe radioactive fire (arguably the coolest thing about the old Godzilla - why change a thing like that?), and it's not indestructible (again, another cool trait of the original creature is lost). The old Godzilla waded through buildings, fire, missiles, lasers, EVERYTHING, on a mission of total destruction; the American Godzilla runs around New York, squawking and burrowing underground like a camera-shy mole. Pathetic.Godzilla is one of the greatest science fiction icons out there, despite the negative (and poorly informed) opinions of his American viewers. This movie, however, is a poor tribute to the big G, and an astounding waste of money as well. The original films are full of great imagery, ranging from poetic to just downright funky. There are no compelling visuals here to equal the sight of Mothra hatching and spreading its wings in "GMK," or Godzilla squaring off against a three-headed gold dragon in the "Ghidorah" films, etc. With all of the imaginative imagery removed, along with the Japanese culture, social commentary, and mysticism, the Godzilla concept is stale and ludicrous.As the closing credits for this movie began to roll, I groaned. Audibly. That's the only time I've ever done something like that in a movie. I mean, how hard is it to get this concept right? All I wanted was a radiation-shooting, indestructible dinosaur smashing through a city. I didn't even expect the subtexts to survive. But my modest expectations were not met. Godzilla is not only an inaccurate adaptation, it's also boring, and that's just plain unforgivable.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2004-03-07</date>
		<username>DrLenera</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Makes the worst of the Japanese ones look like Citizen Kane</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Godzilla is the ultimate in dumb blockbuster film-making,from the masters who gave us the dumb blockbuster Stargate and the dumb blockbuster Independence Day. However,at least those two movies were enjoyable and succeeded in what they set out to do. Godzilla manages to be a failure on every level. Obviously Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich regarded the Japanese Godzilla films as cheap rubbish and thought it would be easy to do better. Ironically,there is far more fun and even wit to be found in five minutes of something like Godzilla V Megalon {to pick a very silly example of the Japanese series}then in all of the American Godzilla.Perhaps if it had not been called Godzilla than one might be able to forgive a Godzilla that is basically a giant mutated iguana,that runs away from the military and doesn't even bother to cause much destruction. It is an insult to fans of Godzilla. But even if you forget about the original Godzilla this is an amazingly bad,inept movie. The effects are shoddy and mostly take place in heavy rain,probably to help obscure them a little. One area where the film could have outdone the Japanese Godzilla films is in destructive spectacle,but we are even denied that. The script's idea of characterisation is to have Jean Reno's French scientist moan about American coffee,and it can't even come up with an interesting way to kill Godzilla. There are loads of gaffs,such as a Godzilla who can run fast but can't even catch up with one car,or Godzilla hiding underground undetected,and the filmmakers have so little evident interest in their monster that they devote almost an entire middle third to a Jurassic Park rerun with lots of baby Godzillas {read Raptors}. Composer David Arnold admitted that he did not know what to do with the film,and it shows.Horrifyingly,the filmmakers planned a sequel,but public indifference to the film put paid to that. At least good came of it-lots of the originals were released on video and showed viewers of this film what both a Godzilla film and a good monster movie was. Most people still think of the Japanese Godzilla whan the name is mentioned. Despite all this,there is still potential for a good American version.Maybe one day........</fullReview>

		<username>Elswet</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>It's the attack of Jurassiczilla!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a very good movie. But the name "Godzilla" should have never been attached to it. As a monster flick it is quite good. But this is NOT the Godzilla I love.I'm going to try to be fair here. I LOVE the hokey old campy "Godzilla" monster movies of the 50's and the 60's...the 70's and the 80's even. And the idea of Godzilla being an irradiated iguana is preposterous. That not withstanding, this is still a good production; highly entertaining; and creatively directed, enacted and presented.Matthew Broderick is wonderful in his role as Dr. Niko "The Worm Guy" Tatopoulos (Project X, Ferris Beuler's Day Off, Election, etc). I've never been much of a fan of his work because I've never been able to identify with his characters. And I thought he REEKED in "Inspector Gadget," but to his credit, that was more the fault of the direction and a really stupid script, than his.Maria Pitillo (Olivia Honey of Roseanne Barr's "She-Devil") demonstrated her best talents in my opinion; the best of her career. (For my review of She-Devil, please click my name and then click the corresponding link.) After a long string of obscure titles, this vehicle gave her a chance to show her true abilities. Her portrayal of Audrey Timmonds is open and appears genuine. She makes you care what happens to her character. That is the start of a good performance. But she never loses that open quality which makes you feel as if you know the character as a person. That is the mark of a great performance; such as the one with which she presents to the viewer in this production.Although the scene in which Dr. Tatopolous finds himself standing inside the footprint of Godzilla was directly ripped off from the '76 remake of "King Kong," the rest of the movie was quite creatively done; written, directed, filmed and presented. I had a lot of fun with this movie, by ignoring the constant references to Godzilla, itself. The "monster" featured in this film is NOT Godzilla, but rather some "Jurassic Park" rip-off of Godzilla. I can enjoy the movie for what it is, rather than what it is supposed to be. What it is supposed to be is a modernized remake of a classic monster/horror movie. What it is, is a top quality monster movie which bears NO resemblance whatsoever to the original.PLOT: "Godzilla" is a colossal irradiated iguana who has come to NYC. The US Army, Corps of Engineers, and a band of French nationals know that "Godzilla" has found a home in the sewers of NYC, but have no idea where. After bombing and blowing up several buildings (the Chrysler Building, for one..."Negative impact?! That's the Chrysler Building we're talking about here!" Mayor of New York City), they finally decide to listen to their hi-jacked expert, Dr. Nico Tatopoulos, and allow him to bait the monster to lure it out into the open. Well, that works, but not as planned. (Do their plans EVER work right? lol) So now, Dr. Tatopoulos, his ex girlfriend (a would-be reporter), and the leader of the French Secret Service unit sent here to monitor and intervene in the capture of the monster, must go down into the sewers to find this elusive terror. Dr. Tatopoulos determines through scientific methodologies and just good old fashioned horse sense, that the monster is in NYC to find a breeding ground for his/its(?) brood of world-dominating spawn. It seems that it reproduces asexually and therefore needs no mate. "What's the fun in that?" Audrey Timmonds. But when they discover that our little "friend" has not only been busy, but very Very busy, in its egg-laying capacity, no one will listen to Nico's insistent pleadings to destroy the building in which the eggs reside, and it is up to our hero to save the day.Excellent monster movie, if you can just ignore the obvious and constant "Godzilla" references. Horrid, atrocious, blasphemy of a remake in the field of "Godzilla" movies.As a Godzilla movie, it rates a 1.2/10.As a monster movie, it rates an 8.9/10 from...the Fiend :.</fullReview>

		<username>chvylvr80</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>and then Godzilla wept</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm a Godzilla fan. So you can imagine my anguish at seeing Godzilla for the first time. Part of Godzilla's magic is that his movies are corny. A guy in a rubber suit fights other guys in rubber suits. Bad dubbing, bad music, and fun for all. Godzilla shouldn't have been made because what kills Godzilla, besides the fact that he looks like no Godzilla before him, is special effects. State of the art CGI is unwelcome in a Godzilla movie, and the production team of Devlin and Emmerich deserved a bomb after the undeserved success of Independence Day. The cast is disposable just like real Godzilla movies. New York takes a little beating and the army gets humiliated. Everything is in place except for the Godzilla that isn't. Bottom Line: This is a movie that should never have been made. That said, you shouldn't be seeing it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-02-22</date>
		<username>Bob_Tanaka</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Good God NOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What IDIOT decided it would be a good idea to make an American Godzilla movie? That's like haveing James Bond work for the CIA. It just isn't done! But, I tend to be generous whenever I watch this movie (always it's so me and my friend can make fun of it) I prefer to view it as a some-what passible remake of "The Beast From 20000 Fathoms". I mantain that the stupidest idea in recent filmaking history is the decision to try to pass this off as a Godzilla movie. It's not. Just because it has a monster named "Godzilla" Tramping around a major city doesn't make it a Godzilla movie. The impossibly stupide (with the exception of the French guys and the two military officers) human actors are given the front stage, GINO (Godzilla In Name Only) is in barly half the scenes and doen't hold it's own (I'm not going to honor it with a gender) at all. But I think it does look like a Rhedosaur quit a bit, plus the similar plot lines (Returning to it's nesting/breeding grounds and tramping NYC). If they had done this as a remake of TBFTTF, it might have been watchable. But, seeing them try to pass of a plump, light-blue, camera-shy, personality-less, over-grown-bipedal-iguana-komodo-dragon-hybread as the beloved Kaiju, is just WRONG! It's enough to make any G-fan sick!I'll end this saying that if they do go through with their plan to release a sequal to this abomination in 2004, Godzilla's 50th birthday, then I think we should add that as the 8th deadly sin.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-01-19</date>
		<username>Dianne B. Dee (Chomolungma)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>NOT AS BAD AS IT MAY SEEM...LOOSE THE NAME THOUGH</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In direct response to this movie and the many comments on both sides of the fence on this issue, I thought another look at the movie was due. What I found wasn't a bad movie. At least not as bad as I first perceived. This version of "Godzilla" is not bad as a movie apart from the series I remember as a child from the great Toho Movie Company. The only thing I wish is that it had lost the title of that Japanese Kaiju Monster. "Godzilla" for me always stood in one realm: Mythological. The whole background of the story of the original monster meant that it had to do with the crucible of fantasy and myth. The great dragon come up from the hellfire of man's folly to do battle with legendary beasts then go once again into the pit to resurrect itself again and again when the need arose. "Gojira" as he is known to Eastern cultures is that legendary beast. He is so known for his mythic birth, death and rebirth that I think it's hard to think of anything else with the name attached to it.With this Emmerich/Devlin production, I think what the purists have issue with is the treatment of our mythological monster. The only things left in tact from the original was the roar, the birth and the name. And on a whole the movie is not bad...but not as a "Godzilla" film. Some of the other reviews stated that this movie is just a "sequel" of sorts to Jurassic Park. They're right. This monster and it's offspring are very much like the Raptors from Jurassic Park. Everything about their appearance and nature conjure the ferocious little creatures from the Universal release. And I think that is what should have happened. It should have either remained as a "fish out of water" story much along the same lines as the remake of King Kong (1977), or it should have broken apart from the mythology of "Godzilla" and made it's own statement. The story of nuclear tests isn't just a Japanese-owned concept. Yes they made the need for nuclear disarmament a frontburner topic, then cloaked it in such a way for younger audiences to understand the higher meanings. This is what Devlin and Emmerich should have done. Made an Americanized tale with the same impact as the Japanese version but not called it Godzilla.The effects are top notch. The casting, in a way, typical of an American made movie. Done for kitche rather than substance. That is a lesser flaw. The redemption is in Jean Reno's "Roache". He is a class act all the way. In a sense recreating his role of Leon from "The Professional", his role of a French Secret Service guy trying to "clean up" his country's sins in Pacific nuclear testing is brilliant. A star in Devlin and Emmerich's column. Maria Patillo is also good for what she does. Her need to redeem herself in the eyes of Matthew Broderick's "Nick" is a good storyline and Hank Azaria's "Animal" is a good sidekick who provides most of the movie's best quips and one-liners. And Broderick himself, does as he always does: Stumbles his way around in the movie trying to find out if he belongs. Again, these are lesser evils.What makes this movie good is it's use of New York landmarks and makes not one attempt to keep the city as sacrosanct. Coming on the heels of the September 11, 2001 attacks on the city, the reminders of the army and airforce presence is a little disturbing, but it is good that all these things haven't been airbrushed out. To do so would be ridiculous. This is just a movie. And I think that is how this movie should ultimately be judged. On its own merits rather than on the mythology of another nation. The creature is good. The design is in line with komodo dragons who inhabit the islands of the French atolls in the Pacific. So it is possible for this monster to look like it does. The situations that the creature finds itself in are also plausible, though I still don't know how and why New York was chosen as its stomping ground. That it came from the Pacific and trekked its way across the world just to nest in Madison Square Gardens is just one of those little sniggling difficulties I had with the movie. The old Gojira of the movies always had his beef with the Japanese. Tokyo or Osaka were always prime ground for Gojira's rants, but again I don't understand why this Godzilla didn't go after Los Angeles or San Francisco or Hawaii for that matter. But again a minor bit of nitpicking. LAX would have provided a good nesting ground. And to see it interact with the HOLLYWOOD sign would have been a personal touch that would have been uproarious in the face of how the town takes itself entirely way too seriously.The homages this movie pays to its predecessor are subtle. Necessary to keep it in line with the origins of the 1954 Japanese non-Raymond Burr version. And some of the other homages to movies like "Jaws" and "King Kong" are evident. I say that this movie should be taken on its own and not as part of the Kaiju Showa, Heisei or millennium series. For anyone to say this movie needn't have been made is silly. It has its moments and again is not all that bad as a stand-alone in line with Emmerich and Devlin's other disaster flick "Independence Day" but not as original as "Stargate". To bash it outright is also silly. The raison d'étre of this movie can be that as a companion piece to the Japanese version. As I said, it just should have lost the name. Calling it "The Beast" or "It" could have sufficed and not have caused such an uproar to the legions of Godzilla fans around the world. I think that is where Devlin and Emmerich stumbled over themselves...to think they could have rescued a legend and made it "better" was a fine bit of hubris on their part. One cannot hope to eradicate over forty years of a series of magical movies and claim the franchise overnight. Some bit of humility would have been appreciated. I think that is where the schism between the purists and the newbies ripped wide open. Devlin and Emmerich should have been mindful of that fact. That they weren't shows they had no intention of honouring the original Godzilla. That was a shame. And since when is suitmation a dead art? Sometimes computer CGI gets a little boring. It's good to see some ingenuity still exists. That Toho in its newer films haven't completely succumbed to Western commercialism is refreshing. I did love the "homage" Toho payed to the 1998 film with its "Godzilla 2000" release. The recreation of certain scenes from the Devilin/Emmerich movie shows that there was no ill will towards the filmmakers. In fact, I feel it was an attempt to show that even Gojira has a sense of humour.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>A G-FAN's WORST NIGHTMARE</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a modern day rampaging monster flick, it isn't too bad. As a modern day rampaging monster flick bearing the name GODZILLA, it's just plain awful. I first got to see this during G-CON, a gathering of Godzilla fans from across the country and almost everyone agreed that any resemblence between this one and the original was a dirty shame. (One of the actors from the original Godzilla series, who was a featured guest at the convention, walked out during the movie-can't say that I blame him). Granted, GODZILLA '98 was nowhere near as bad as, say, KING KONG LIVES, but it's painful to watch, knowing all along that a far superior remake had been in the works by director Jon DuMont (SPEED, STARSHIP TROOPERS) and had been canned just before being picked up by Devlin &amp; Emmerich.And by the way, the acting is hideous. Only Hank Azaria and the monster( I refuse to refer to that mutated iguana as Godzilla) turn in a decent performance.Rating: *1/2</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I caught this movie on T.V. the other day, and it was spectacular. An all star cast matches wits against a nuclear altered iguana. Godzilla is a nonstop, heart pounding thrill ride all the way. The audience is shocked, however, when Godzilla is seemingly killed about a half hour into the movie. The audience is shocked again to see that in the end--wait, wait, I won't give away the ending for those of you who haven't seen it(If you haven't seen it yet, what are you waiting for?). The audience is confronted with a new feature to Godzilla: he reproduces. Wait, what am I saying? Godzilla has had a child before, so I guess it's nothing new, but it has never been to this magnitude before. He is able to lay two hundred eggs at a time. The nuclear blast makes Godzilla and all of his offspring asexual, so that means if Godzilla can lay two hundred eggs, each one of those eggs can lay two hundred more eggs.Let's see, that makes about...WOW! That's a lot of Godzillas. Behind all that action/adventure, and dazzleling special effects, the movie has an overall good message about the world: "Don't let the French handle any nuclear weapons." I'm sure you'll love the 1998 movie, "Godzilla" as much as I did.</fullReview>

		<username>badap145</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rip-Off!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin's take on the Big-G ripped off so many movies so blantantly it's pathetic. Here are some very specific examples: The whole Madison Square Garden sequence is just an overblown version of the kitchen scene of JURASSIC PARK, w/ little 'Zillas replacing the velociraptors. The nest full of eggs is from ALIENS. And watch the ending, when Godzilla is killed and Brodrick is looking at him. There is complete silence except for Godzilla's heart-beat slowing to a crawl, and finally the crowd cheers. Now go back a few decades, to the remake of KING KONG (I think in '75 or '76) and watch this ending. Replace Godzilla with Kong, and Brodrick with Jessica Lang, and you have identical endings. It's so obvious someone probably mentioned it already. Not to mention Emmerich ripped off his own, much better, previously made action movie, INDEPENDENCE DAY. As for the "new and improved" Godzilla himself, he's just a big dumb schmoe who couldn't grab that little taxi if it was sitting in a desert missing all 4 wheels. The real Godzilla would whip his ass from Manhattan all the way back to his native stomping grounds of Tokyo. Actually, that would make a GOOD Godzilla movie, heh heh.</fullReview>

A creature of this size can burrow underground without leaving a trace? NO WAY. The creature then pops out and once more terrorizes the city. The city is supposed to go through an evacuation, but, if this happens, it is cleverly concealed, since it remains populated with myriads of people. The creature supposedly lays a few zillion eggs, requiring massive efforts to destroy them, apparently successful until the ending. I wonder how Matthew Broderick managed to get himself trapped into this turkey. He was excellent in Torch Song Trilogy, The Freshman and Glory, but this was a real mistake for him. 		<username>flickjunkie-3</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Over-Hyped Nonsense.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Godzilla had an intriguing trailer. But, lots of films have enthralling trailers and are bad films. Godzilla is one of them.Nuclear testing accidentally resurrects Godzilla, a huge foot monster with a big appetite. The monster takes Manhattan, and it's up to a select group of people, including Dr. Niko Tatopolous (Matthew Broderick) and Phillipe Roache (Jean Reno), to stop the monster, and it's soon-to-be-hatching eggs, before Godzilla's destroy the whole city, and maybe even the world.The postage-stamp-sized plot is poorly written. Everything is so repetitve! Godzilla attacks almost everyone on boats, and every time he comes to town it is raining like heck. Also, here's a question for ya. Why does Godzilla eat none of Manhatten's residents and it's babies do? There are many more questions to be answered, and mostly everything important about films has been ripped apart here. It has some slight pleasures, the monster itself is pretty well-done for special effects and the dumb acting is sometimes laughably enjoyable. But the characters are unlikeable, the plot is predictable and Godzilla, the monster itself, would suit a dancing film rather than a try-hard thriller.A pointless addition for Matthew Broderick's once-good career, Godzilla is nothing short of a let-down.I rate Godzilla 4 out of 10.</fullReview>

		<username>(david_popa@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>

		<shortDescription>Incredibly BAD movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As I see it there are three categories of bad movies 1) those that are boring 2) those that are unintentionally funny and 3) those that move you from the bottom of your soul by being so incredibly, mesmerisingly awful. Godzilla falls into the third category, and it's a straight insult towards the viewer by being as brainless and stupid as it is.Godzilla is one of those "Independence Day"-offsprings that are trying to cash in on the publics craving for special FX and stuff blowing up. Godzilla's sky high budget goes alltogether to waste, and the director has only succeeded in producing a two hour long piece of S**t! The director has made a sloppy job on everything, I don't think he even spell-checked the script. The actors don't seem to know what they're doing, and they don't seem to care either. Same goes for the viewer.The dialogue is some of the silliest I've ever heard, even the monster is more human than the main characters. The plot consists of people screaming, buildings exploding and high-tech babble, and it doesn't get any better towards the end, either. The result would be a very boring two hours, but there's one more fatal flaw.The very fact that someone actually thought that this could be entertaining to someone is incredible! The huge underestimating of the viewer is to me very insulting, and the na?vity of the producers is unbelievable. How someone could invest 100 million dollars on this, is past my understanding, just think how many brilliant indie-movies could have been made with that money!If you want to keep your faith in the future of film industry, don't watch this. If you're expecting another "Plan Nine", prepare for worse. There is no reason for someone to watch this, so don't. You'll end up wasting two hours of your life like me, and believe me you don't want to spend them this way!!!!!!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The rubber suit was better</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>From the team that made Independence Day, you expect this to be the coolest movie of the year. It isn't. Starting with Godzilla, here's a giant lizard that has no presence. At least when you saw the guy in the rubber suit, you sat up expecting something to happen. Not here. Matthew Broderick is horribly miscast as Nick Tatapolis (named after Patrick Tatapolis, Centropolis FX whiz). You never believe he has the analytical skills befitting a scientist. Other characters, except Animal, are weak. Jean Reno has the best character as a French operative, and should have been the focus of the movie if Godzilla wasn't going to be allowed that privilege. The dialogue is flatter than a script page ("That's a lot of fish." No kidding, Sherlock). The action is contrived, with helicopters that fly forward instead of up to escape the lizard. The opening has some effective moments, but feels a lot like the opening of ID4. With this movie, Godzilla isn't the only one laying eggs left and right.</fullReview>

		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>One way to describe a summer blockbuster: ALL SHOW AND NO GO!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>We're at the boiling point of classic movie / TV series remakes, folks! Combined as a rip-off of JURASSIC PARK by modern standards, GODZILLA is another in recent attempts to win over new generations of young moviegoers. It's one of the few that fail to dupe their original counterparts, all because of big budget visuals and lackluster writing. That pretty much explains why Sony wanted another blockbuster franchise since MEN IN BLACK to gain control of the movie industry, and I'm sorry to say that their luck has run out. An aged and weakling plot isn't the only disease it suffers from. Godzilla's character design is a terrible pity and so does its politically incorrect New York setting. For DVD owners, the best use of your new disc is a doorstop for expensive graphics, and that's it! If you think it's a waste of money, consider these important facts: $50 million on promotional theatrical advertising! 8 1/2 minutes of end credits! A soundtrack album featuring The Wallflowers! Need I say more? We can expect better movies in the future, but not like this! I'll stick to those classic Japanese monster movies, thank you!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Spielberg must have thrown up</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Anyone remember the trailer for Godzilla ? Godzilla's foot smashes a T-Rex skeleton on exhibition in a museum. This was at a time when we weren't quite sure if Roland Emmerich had talent. ID4 was cheesy but no doubt had its moments. 15 years later we know for sure that he is one of the worst directors ever to have made it to Hollywood. Flicking through his works that were yet to come and insult our intelligence, I am now sure that Emmerich is the one big (not great!) Hollywood director to even make Michael Bay look "maybe not quite as bad". Comparing Godzilla to Jurassic Park fits quite nicely as both film makers had the ambition of creating a fun and exciting roller-coaster ride of a film. But JP was about ideas. It had some profundity to it where Godzilla was merely about size and discarded the actual appeal of the original. Spielberg was able to create suspense and tension. In JP he refined it to perfection. The T Rex was beautifully designed and somewhat had the weight of a believable entity. Godzilla's design was ridiculously puberty-boyish, had no weight, didn't scare. The set pieces were awful. The logic gaps were a disgrace. Matthew Broderick was a bad cast. The reporter's behavior was as non-sequitur as that of a schizophrenic idiot. And then the rain... Godzilla's dead.. Broderick waddles up to its carcass and now we seem to be supposed to feel sorry for this misunderstood creature.. I mean it just wanted to destroy the city and kill us all :( I can't understand how anyone could ever like or even appreciate this peace of cinematic horse.. manure. I hate the fact that I watched it all the way through. I'll never be able to get that time back.. ever.Conclusion: Jurassic Park relates to Godzilla like Spielberg relates to Emmerich or like Marilyn Monroe relates to Paris Hilton or like Dolphins relate to Leeches. :)</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>So Many Special Effects, So Little Story</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wanted to like this. I was told by one of my students that a big buck remake of Godzilla was coming out. Then, like happens too often, the big bucks were spent on eye candy and not on a really engaging film. While the lizard was certainly amazing, the way he jumps around and squashes things is almost too formidable. Had he been bent on total destruction there would have been a total annihilation of New York in a few minutes. Of course, his motivations lie elsewhere. He certainly is better than a guy in a Godzilla suit, but eventually get to the humans. I'm not quite sure what to think of Matthew Broderick. He is one of the most bland people I have every seen. Even on Letterman he comes off as the dull guy next door. He also still looks like he's about sixteen. Instead of building really great suspense and waiting for the lizard to make its movie, we have these scientific ramblings. There is humor injected here and there. The newspaper people are ridiculous. The French guys are so out of place that all they do is confuse everyone. Just because you are French, doesn't mean you are stupid. It is a Western country and the people know what's going on in the world. French Roast coffee, indeed! A lame excuse for an on screen commercial. I tried watching this again and was befallen with the same basic endless boredom. The special effects are nonpareil, but after a while they only get you to first base.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-07-01</date>
		<username>stevenw-1</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Major potential ignored by makers in favor of "typical" American event flick.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I, to this day, want to like and enjoy this film. Alas, appreciation will never come since the film seems to have been made specifically NOT to homage the original films from Japan. Instead, it seems created to...hell, I don't know. It certainly didn't thrill. There is not an ounce of wit, charm nor are there any thrills to be had other than a car chase (where have you seen those before?) and a people chase (Raptor-like monsters that are fast, but not fast enough to catch slow-running actors! Spielberg's dinos AND approach have yet to be matched). This a damn shame considering this film cost enough to feed a small country or help re-build Iraq. We American's waited for this???? I think the film suffers from a bit of presumption on behalf of the Hollywood duo who made this. They seem to want to avoid anything that made the Japanese films charming. In this flick, there are no colorful sets, no complex plots mixing the monster action with the human action, no rival monsters...and that's just to name a few. This film offers a few explosions (Hollywood films live and die by their explosions - original, eh?), a car chase and some military fire (okay - I liked those). As for Emmerich/Roland's take on the lead character...boy this is one camera shy monster! This giant lizard (yeah that's all. Just an overgrown lizard with zero personality. It is so undefined and kept hidden most of time that he hardly seems a threatening presence! It doesn't cause too much damage, either - not in these faux politically correct times. NYC is "evacuated" in a matter of hours. Now that is the one truly funny moment in the movie. Overall, the film just has too many pretensions to be a really engaging thriller. Why bother if (as a filmmaker) you're not gonna thrill us besides showing us bits and pieces that we've already seen in better films? This "Godzilla" is supposedly as tall as a skyscraper but you'd never know it since this one changes size in every other shot and has an annoying habit of crouching really, really low to fit into the film frame...*sigh* so much potential flushed down the toilet for us fans of giant monster pictures-especially one as expensive as this one. Roger Corman made bad films (fun, charming and memorable ones at that!) for pocket change compared to the 100 million plus $$$ here. The Emmerich team STILL came up short ("Size matters" indeed). This film made money since the curious (including myself) bought into it...with regret. The film took a nosedive in popularity (and $$$) as time went on and lacked the legs to become a true blockbuster. Moviegoers wisened up with time. Glad to know I'm not the only one out there...</fullReview>
	</review>

It was also killed to easily, the Japan version would never be taken down that easily...they always have to come up with some new and innovative way of getting him back in the sea, not just slam a couple of missiles into him. And Godzilla is not a lizard, but a dinosaur a mix of T-rex and stegosaurus. 		<username>Jerald</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Godzilla?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Warning: The following may contain spoilers. Read no further if you don't want any detailed information about this movie.Being the Godzilla fan that I am, I was both excited and skeptical about the "new" Godzilla. Excited because there would be more "Godzilla " for me to see. Skeptical because I didn't know if they could pull it off.Did They? Let's see...My whole life Godzilla has been a man in a suit. While, throughout the years this suit has changed (almost every single film used a different suit), Godzilla still looked generally the same. I knew going into the film that there was a new look, and was pretty open minded to that. I also knew that he was to be computer generated (CGI), which I was anxious to see. Upon seeing Godzilla in the film, I was very pleased with the look of the creature, but felt that maybe this film should have been called something else. I don't know what, but just not Godzilla. Well, I guess they knew that if they had made a film with it's own identity, they would have been taking a greater risk. We all know it's not about risk, it's about money. Would I have been as excited about a film called "Iguanasaur"? Probably not.The Godzilla effect looked good and the creatures introduction was very good. The audience gets to see the creature a little at a time while he has an exciting romp through town. That, however, is about the best of it.The acting? Bad. Every time Mathew Broderick opens his mouth he sounds like an 8 year old boy. The other actors are not much better, except for Jean Reno, who does an ok job. However, if you saw him in The Professional, he looks like a caricature of himself here.As far as the other effects go, I could have done without several scenes. They can suspend my disbelief enough to make a "giant dinosaur thing" seem real, but then try to tell me that a fisherman is going to get his line tangled in something that looks like it's more than 200 yards away? Dock scene: Cut it! Helicopters flying very quickly between buildings? Cut it! Bad CGI helicopter flight paths? (one of my pet peeves) Cut it! And that horrible "drive out of the mouth" scene! Cut that too!The part of the movie I liked least is the velociraptor- uh, I mean baby Godzilla submovie. They spent way too much time on this and it really detracts from the "Big Creature" feel of the movie. Even so, keep your eyes peeled for the baby Godzilla with the big bag of popcorn in it's mouth, it's really funny. Baby Godzilla submovie: Cut it!Well, if we were to cut the scenes from the movie that detracted from it, we would have little left but the trailers for the film, which were excellent.Did they pull it off? No. Did it make money? Yes.All in all, it's the Halloween III of Godzilla movies! (Halloween III had no relation to any other Halloween film)</fullReview>

		<date>2012-10-09</date>
		<username>ciarandino</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>An enjoyable movie, but as had been said a billion times before, it's not Godzilla</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a highly enjoyable movie, with some good scenes in it, and I have a lot of nostalgia for this movie as well. However, I do of course have some gripes. The biggest one is the huge lack of Godzilla in this film. You'd think that a film called Godzilla might actually feature, ya know, Godzilla, but instead we get a completely different monster that we're expected to think of as Godzilla. Now don't get me wrong, GINO (Godzilla In Name Only, as pretty much every G fan knows) is an awesome monster. He's very well designed, and pretty damn cool. But really, the movie should have been called something else, because calling it Godzilla is false advertising. Heck, the director, Roland Emmerich, didn't even like Godzilla movies very much, making one wonder what on earth made him want to direct one (money). But in spite of all this, this is still a highly enjoyable monster movie.Now the thing that I like the most in this movie are the scenes with the monster. They're all very enjoyable. First is the scene where GINO attacks a Japanese fishing ship. It's very effective when the monster shows up on the sonar and everyone is freaking out, and then the awesome pause where we hear that ominous groan the creature makes before all hell breaks loose and its claws break straight through the ship. Next of course is when GINO shows up in NYC, with a brilliant shot to reveal him rising from the sea, and a subsequent scene which shows as little as possible of the monster as it rampages through the city streets. Of course there are also the scenes where GINO goes up against the military, which are all enjoyable scenes.Now for the things that annoy me, apart from the movie not actually featuring Godzilla. For one thing, the characters. They are all 2 dimensional idiots. The only likable one is the french guy, who's name I cannot recall. Next is the fact that they set up the monster as a sympathetic creature, and yet expects us to celebrate when it dies. It spoils a kind of sad moment when it dies, and there's silence, and suddenly everyone bursts into applause. And of course, there are the baby Godzilla's. They kind of felt like an unnecessary addition to the story, pretty much just filler. So over all, I think it's an enjoyable movie with some great moments, but of course, it does have a good number of flaws, and calling it Godzilla was just milking the name, because it was really its own thing. Anyway, that's all I have to say on the matter. Ta ta</fullReview>

		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Most disappointing film experience I've ever had (well, almost)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I bought into the hype when this came out in 1998. I was younger then and went to go see it opening day with my friend. He loved it, but the entire time I saw there awestruck thinking to myself, "Wow, this is actually BORING!" It's not that the film is just stupid. All blockbusters are, after all. It's that Roland Emmerich is so inept here at delivering any sort of entertainment value -- the film takes itself way too seriously for a summer popcorn flick, trying to insert depth and dialogue - both backfire miserably.Matthew Broderick is sorely miscast as the lead hero and Jean Reno has perhaps the only good role in the entire film.The CGI sequences are alright I suppose but compared to today's effects, they're outdated -- and when a film relies entirely on effects to wow over its audience, you know it's in trouble.The end of the film turns into "Jurassic Park" with little Godzillas running around chasing people like Raptors.This movie is too long, too stupid, too pretentious and too boring.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-03-23</date>
		<username>Ben Auletta, Jr. (djben1)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>American Version of Godzilla not worth the time.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You've come a long way baby. Godzilla which Sony hoped would be the big movie of the 1998 summer season, stomped its way on to a record number of screens its opening weekend. Once the star of 22(At the time of the films release) Japanese films, Starting out in 1954, Godzilla' latest American version is handled by director/Writer Roland Emmerich and producer/writer Dean Devlin. You may remember Emmerich and Devlin as the team that bought you the summer blockbuster "Independence Day." With a reported budget of $125 million and in excess of $50 million worldwide in advertising, does Godzilla live up to all the roaring? How believable is Matthew Broderick ("Cable Guy") cast in the lead human role as the scientist Nick Tatopoulus? Although some may feel it's a good attempt to pull it off, Broderick seems out of place in this role, maybe due to the Hollywood typecasting that makes it hard for moviegoers to see an actor out of character. As I entered the theater, I was apprehensive. Is this a kiddy movie or am I just not ready to see another campy monster film? Wellis that not what Godzilla is all about? Did not the Japanese seek out to make a campy film that mocks the sci-fi monster genre? If that is the case, than Hollywood pulled off another one. Emmerich shows the classic campy satire of the original films throughout the movie from the scene of fruitless air attacks to the monster himself. Emmerich could not find an improvement in the voice of the monster so he borrowed the infamous roar from the Japanese films. Thank heavens he did not decide to make Godzilla speak, as the monster did in one of his past films. I don't think I could have handled that. One other actor of note is Jean Reno as Philippe Roche, insurance investigator. As in all films I've seen him in, he brings great seriousness and acting to the role. Also Godzilla, the monster, I feel was not as campy as his Japanese counterpart. Going into this movie I was ready to see a forgettable film. Well, maybe it was better than I thought even with its simplistic and somewhat predictable script. I think fans of Godzilla will delight in another visit with the prehistoric movie star. Kids who may or may not have seen any of the original 22 films will undoubtedly love this kid-friendly movie, although young children may find it way to scary to watch. Adults on the other hand, may find it hard to swallow. Rating 2.5 stars..</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-28</date>
		<username>kitsenugari</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>somehow manages to be cheesier than the original series</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Every critic on the planet thought Godzilla demonstrated with absolute perfection what not to do when making a film, so 'I was bored' is my best excuse for why I saw this. From the title sequence I knew not to take this movie seriously, or at least, not to take this as a serious movie: Lizards sprawled on rocks wave their tongues as a nuclear bomb explodes. This is real drama, people. When the movie begins, Godzilla has attacked a small island somewhere and people take notice. Well, the stupid people on the planet take notice: a scientist who studies radioactive grubs (hereafter known as worm guy) and some uncouth military leaders whose approach to combat strategies involves a lot of maps with arrows that point in no particular direction.As Godzilla makes his way to New York City, a ditsy and highly irritating wannabe reporter also takes notice because she sees her college sweetie, worm guy (Matthew Broderick), on TV, looking at a big footprint. Apparently this was an attempt at a subplot, but you need a plot before you can have a subplot. The reporter's friends consist of an equally insipid co-worker and her loud cameraman husband. He's played by Hank Azaria, apparently the only one who was actually paid to act.Okay, so FINALLY the lizard gets to New York City (he got stuck in traffic in the Lincoln Tunnel), and goes to see `Rent' on Broadway. Not really, but that would've been fun, huh? His less-than-subtle arrival is actually a pretty cool sequence, with the ground bouncing up and down and people staring around, though it copies a bit too much from Jurassic Park. The sluggish, hackneyed dialogue and the numerous shots of gaping-mouthed onlookers soon gets real old, real fast. We get it: Godzilla's here. Within 10 minutes, Godzilla tears through the place and then vanishes. Did I forget to mention that Godzilla is 100 feet tall and weighs more than 10 elephants? His disappearance is announced by `Melrose Place's' Doug Savant, playing one of many vapid military officers who whines through the entire film and manages to accomplish nothing. The film contains lots of helicopter-following-Godzilla/Godzilla-following-helicopter chases, but the thought of 14 Tomcat choppers zipping through the maze of NYC buildings while chasing a giant lizard is more unbelievable than the reptile they're after. What can a helicopter do to what is essentially a giant salamander taller than the Empire State Building? And who would've thought to fly ABOVE the buildings? That's another problem with the film - there are too many easy answers that these supposedly bright people can't figure out. And no one seems to be frightened at all that they might die. The military and press calmly set up camp across the river in New Jersey, because we all know that Godzilla, who swam across the Atlantic Ocean, would never be able to wade across the Hudson River to eat his enemies. Meanwhile, worm guy thinks of a brilliant plan to smoke out the elusive gargantuan lizard by FEEDING HIM. How scientific. Along the way there seem to be several attempts at a bonding between Broderick and Godzilla, but somehow that just doesn't play across on screen. Go figure. The only suspenseful part that brings much needed excitement to the movie occurs when little 9' tall baby Godzillas hatch inside Madison Square Garden (they're trying to score Knicks tickets). I would have thought I was watching an original film if it weren't for the fact that it felt like exactly Alien meets Jurassic Park: the Lost World.  So finally it ends (I won't spoil *that* for you), the wannabe reporter pulls out her can o' whoop-ass on her boss and then reconciles with worm guy, and you leave feeling sorry for the big G. To sum up, most of the special effects were not special at all. For the majority of the movie Godzilla is hiding under New York City so we don't even get to see him. Plus, his fire-breathing skills are nearly non-existent, when they would clearly be an effective weapon against flammable New York City and the less-than-competent armed forces (plus, adding fire always ups a movie's excitment factor). There was no plot, horrible acting, miscasting, an unbelievably stupid military, too many news-happy reporters, and lots of stereotypically mysterious, coffee-drinking, chain-smoking, complaining French people, who somehow had a hand in it all. If I had submitted this script to a studio, they would have taken me out in back and put me out of my misery. Maybe it was trying to make fun of the old Godzilla flicks, but I think it was just bad movie making, considering all the failed wisecracks that were painful to hear. It wasn't the worst movie I've ever seen, but it comes damn close.My grade for "Godzilla": D-</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Karl Self</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Smellier Than Godzilla's Breath In The Morning</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's reminisce about Independence Day. What a movie that was. I remember being dragged into it by a friend who was into action movies, whereas I am more your regular art house cinema goer. At the beginning of IE4 I was complaining about how some people are willing to watch purest American propaganda if there are only a few explosions in it; yet half an hour later I was sitting at the edge of my seat, screaming "nuke the freaks", cheering our boys into battle and spilling my Big Gulp Diet Mountain Dew.Then the original Godzilla movies. Naff, yes, but atmospheric, innovative and entertaining even today, with their hideous dubbing, the C - list American actors dressed as Japanese (including the unavoidable blonde scientist, who's always a bit of a women's lib sympathizer in the beginning) and their Japanese counterparts dressed as American C - list actors, and the lovingly executed special effects.But the 1998 Hollywood Godzilla: oh deary me. What a fall from grace for Roland Emmerich. It is unbelievable that he could have FIRST made IE4, where he got it all right, and straight AFTER that Godzilla, where he simply gets everything wrong. The movie itself: special effects -- solid, but you've all seen it before (literally! it's a cross between Alien and Jurassic Park); the story -- non-existent; the dialogues (the essential OTHER ingredient in an action movie) -- a bunch of monkeys on Prozac briefly hacking away on a type writer would have done better; acting -- if it was possible to force Charlie Chaplin into exile, why not try the same with Maria Pitello? Anything to stop her from publicly putting on her doubtful "I am a little girl with fabulous blonde curly hair toughening up to the Big Apple" expression (and I am using that word liberally here). (Message to Hank Azaria: I feel your pain. Honest, man.)As an aside. Roland - next time you are looking for comical Greek name to base half of the dialogue on: I once had a class mate named Charalambos Korioglokglu. We called him Bobbes.Hey, don't mention it.</fullReview>

		<username>Angus T. Cat</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Doesn't live up to the trailer- I prefer the original Godzilla (or Reptar)!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When the trailer came out showing the pounding of Godzilla's feet getting louder and then the museum scene getting squished my husband and I cheered. But when the film came to the flicks we heard it stank, so we stayed away.Godzilla came on TV last night so I decided to watch it. The buzz was true: it didn't live up to the hype or the legend.The storyline started promisingly, with loads of nuclear blasts and shots of lizards, the Japanese boat getting slashed and sunk, and the old guy screaming Godzilla's Japanese name. But when it switched to Dr. Nick hunting for earthworms and started following him around it quickly turned into another mediocre movie with taglines to tell the audience where the characters were.The love story with Audury was out of a TV movie. Most of the characters were out of TV movies. The special effects were great: the shots of the planes chasing Godzilla around the canyons of New York skyscrapers were breaktaking.But poor Godzilla didn't get to do what he does best: knock down buildings, scream, breathe fire and flatten cars, people, and anything that gets in his way. Godzilla mark 1998 is Godzilla lite. He isn't angry, he rips into buildings by accident with his tail, he's too busy looking for fish. The plot with the eggs was as plausible as Dr Nick discovering Godzilla was pregnant with the aid of drugstore Be Sure tests. The idea of Madison Square Garden full of eggs that started to hatch was awesome, and the baby Godzillas fighting over bags of popcorn was cute, but it was a plot from another film.I was glad when Godzilla came back and started eating the main characters. Why did the writers have to digress with the pregnancy plot? It wasn't the Godzilla everyone knows and loves.The movie needed to focus more on what makes Godzilla great: wailing and stomping buildings, cars, people. The Rugrats' tribute to him with Reptar was right on target. I wanted more shots of mass destruction that made Tommy gurgle and kick over his blocks with joy. I wanted to feel that delight in strength and power too.If this is Godzilla, I prefer Reptar!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-10-16</date>
		<username>(winner55)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>time waster</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There are only two good things in this film, Jean Reno as the French spy, and the editing, which keeps the film moving even when the screenplay clearly does not. For these two reasons alone, it might be worth wasting some time on this, but surely for nothing else.Here are some of the bad qualities of this mess: BAD science: it is physically impossible for this lizard to have laid 200 eggs in two days.BAD history: The French are brought in to hide the fact that it was the US that did most of the nuclear testing in the Pacific.BAD politics: In a State of Emergency military response HQ, the mayor would never be present - he has no authority in such a situation; so why do the soldiers here even tolerate him? BAD story construction: Only a couple missiles to kill off a monster, but two similarly explosive torpedoes can't do the job? And how did the lizard get from Guam to NYC without any further notice - in a single day, apparently. And why? We all know Toho's Godzilla's grudge against Japan, but it's senseless for GINO to swim thousands of miles, just to sleep in a NYC subway.BAD characters: The hero is boringly monotone, in appearance as in speech; the hero's girlfriend is a real bitch and deserved stepping on - why then bring the two of them back together? Are they sadomasochists as well? BAD special effects: The color values of the skin of the big reptiles never change, despite radical variance in tone, amount, and direction of the environmental lighting of any scene. A godzillion dollars on special effects, and they make such a serious goof?! Of course these critters are phony - they look pasted on the screen.BAD in-jokes: The Siskel and Ebert gag was amusing for precisely 10 seconds - unfortunately it was repeated through-out the film. And it is overtly insulting to two critics who deserved our respect, no matter how we disagreed with them.BAD performances: Is Matthew Broderick's face capable of more than one expression? If so, I've never seen it.BAD musical score: the main theme of the film is played over and over again, until we just want some big reptile to step on the orchestra.BAD psychology: The endlessly replayed musical theme is composed to arouse sympathy for the beast, when everything else in the film makes us dislike it. The disjunction is painful.BAD timing: This film goes on and one - the eggs are introduced for no other reason than to prolong a film that desperately needs trimming.I could go on, but what's the point. Roland Emmerich needs to find something other to do with his life, he's clearly not cut out to make movies. In an interview on a featurette in the DVD release of this film, director Roland Emmerich says that he wanted to make a "completely different" Godzilla, the original being - according to him - out of date. Does this man suffer from brain damage? Godzilla doesn't need to be different. Godzilla is the protagonist of a popular ongoing series of films made in Japan. Beginning in 1984, the producers of these films decided they would gradually update the series to take advantage of new special effects technology. They didn't need some snotty Occidental to show them how to do this. They were gracious enough to license out the series to Americans because they know our fascination with these films. I suspect they assumed that an American entry into the series would give it new energy. Instead, their series' title was ripped-off for a remake of a completely other American film.If you're going to make a pastiche of a famous adventure series, you had better find some way to fit your pastiche into the series as a whole. For instance there are many pastiche Sherlock Holmes stories written by authors other than Arthur Conan Doyle. Some of these stories attempt to fill in a gap in the original series - the years following Holmes' struggle with Professor Moriarity at the Reichenbach Falls, when Watson loses touch with Holmes for a few years. So a reader is permitted to imagine Holmes as having lived a whole life - no past Holmes episode is denied; no Holmes story to come is effected. The reader can thus ignore the question of authorship and concentrate on following the adventurous life of the great detective.While the original Godzilla series is not chronologically sequential (A few are, presumably, set in an "alternate universe"), they do share a remarkably consistent set of themes and subtexts. And while the appearance of Godzilla changes over the years, these changes are consistent with the notion that the monster somehow matures with every film.It is utterly pointless, therefore, to make a Godzilla film without any Godzilla in it. It is actually insulting - to the producers of the original series and to its audience - to discard the themes that brought the audience to the original series in the first place. And it is absolutely stupid (and racist) to presume that, because you work in Hollywood rather than Tokyo, you can get away with it.So this is not a Godzilla film - what is it really? It happens to be an over-bloated overly-rewritten remake of the Ray Harryhausen classic, "Beast From 20,000 Fanthoms". That film is also way better than this one; heck, while made in the '50s, even its special effects are better.Again, if you have two hours of spare time, and you can think of nothing else to do with your life, by all means let Emmerich give your brain a visual enema with this movie. But keep the toilet-paper handy, I guarantee watching this will leave a mess to clean-up.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>The_Film_Cricket</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>This ain't Godzilla . . .</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't recognize the Godzilla in this movie as Godzilla. I have seen most of the Toho films from Japan and somehow even though it was a guy in rubber suit he still managed to have a personality. The creature here is a mystery to me ? an overdone special effects lizard left over from the cutting room floor of 'Jurassic Park'. Somehow the more real Godzilla looks, the less impact he has.This answers the key question of why the ad campaign kept Godzilla hidden, not because they had created anything special but because the monster is so uninteresting to look at.The key difference between the Japanese Godzilla movies and this Americanized dreck are too numerous to mention. I will never forget Godzilla's victory dance after his battle in 'Godzilla vs. Ghidra'. This movie doesn't have time for scenes like that because it depends so heavily on its over-inflated budget of special effects. The Hollywood theory seems to be ? If the audience doesn't get it's special effects soon and often it will get up and leave.Somehow in this mess there is a story. Matthew Broderick adds this to his resume, alternating between impressive projects like 'Infinity' and 'Election' and hackneyed special effects movies like 'Godzilla' and 'Inspecter Gadget' as an expert in worm biology and hits upon the discovery that G is a female. Uh-huh. This is the set-up for a retread of the kitchen scene in Jurassic Park, this time in Madison Square Garden which doesn't resonate suspense so much as ? Seen It! The movie is produced and directed by the team of Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin who made a hugh smash with their alien invasion in 'Independence Day' and their other-worldly pyramid scheme in 'Stargate'. Those films had some admirers but I found them as noisy, dimwitted and forgettable as this one.The key problem is that they have tried to make a Godzilla movie with a sense a realism and that doesn't work. You have to make monster movies fun, campy and give the audience something to sink their teeth into. This lazy Godzilla production doesn't seem to much inspired by the Toho Films as the lame American summer special effects movies of recent years.NOTE: May I recommend: Gamera: The Guardian of the Universe, Mighty Peking Man, Godzilla vs. Destroyah and the original King Kong. Trust me.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2014-07-28</date>
		<username>gzilla1998</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>This film should quite simply be renamed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is such a sad, misunderstood film on all accounts. "Godzilla" 1998 is probably one of the worst adaptations ever. Godzilla himself really isn't present at all in the monster character featured: A radical re- design, a cowardly nature, being a biological parent to raptors, death by military, etc. It's no wonder why Toho, Godzilla's parent studio, completely segregated the character from Godzilla, copyrighted it as Zilla, and made it the subject of joke and ridicule in at least two of their later pictures. This film should not be counted as a Godzilla film, reducing the count to 29 movies in total. While it's a horrible Godzilla film, the movie is a decent popcorn flick to watch occasionally if you butt out Godzilla himself. The characters are really not that great, Nick Tatapolus, Animal, and Philipe are just as caricature in nature as all of the characters in Michael Bay's Transformer series. The acting isn't so hot either, Audrey being the worst easily, not to mention the script is occasionally atrocious and meaningless dialogue is everywhere, especially during the beginning. The CGI effects are also dated and cheesy looking when you compare them to Godzilla (2014). However, the monster sequences are still fun to watch and are still entertaining, even if there are a few rip-offs from Jurassic Park here and there. Overall, this movie is a half decent monster flick, but a terrible re-adaptation/imitation of the Godzilla character. Although it may hold nostalgia for myself and others, it's really not as good as some people might try to point out. If you're looking for a monster movie, this one isn't too bad. If you are looking for a Godzilla movie, please stay away from this. It's probably best forgotten and left to sit in the dollar bin.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>German-born director Roland Emmerich is not noted for his subtlety - his previous film was "Independence Day" - and there is nothing subtle about this version of a huge monster ravaging an iconic city, in this case New York. Matthew Broderick struggles to bring some sense to the mayhem, while French actor Jean Reno seems to have wandered into the wrong movie. The script is very poor and the plot almost non-existent, but the special effects are fun in this cross between "King Kong", "Aliens" and "Jurassic Park". There are some familiar Manhatten sights including the Flat Iron Building, the Chrysler Building, Madison Square Garden and Brooklyn Bridge, but the city suffers as much as the audience.</fullReview>

		<username>kdnor2011</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>This movie is bashed, way to much</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I never saw the original Japanese Godzilla, none of them. I've seen clips, and I basically know what it's about, but I have not seen them. Now that may be the reason I like this movie more than others. Believe me, if you are a fan of the Japanese Godzilla movies, I can totally understand why you would hate this movie. And even if you don't, it has flaws, I can see hating it even if you don't like the original. But despite it's flaws, it's many, many flaws, I do enjoy this movie.The CGI on Godzilla did not age well, at all. I mean at night he looks OK, at times. But whenever he appears during the day, and even at certain parts at night he just looks so fake. Maria Pitillo, the actress who played Audrey is horrible. I haven't seen her in anything else so I won't say she is a bad actress, but she certainly couldn't act in this movie. The Pacing is a little off, it doesn't get interesting until Godzilla hits New York. Before that it's very boring. And yes it has quite a few plot holes and errors in logic and continuity, and even geography.Yet despite all those flaws, it's a pretty fun movie to watch. Sure the CG on Godzilla isn't good, but the rest of the effects aren't bad. A lot of practical effects for the destruction of New York city. I actually really like Matthew Broderick in this movie, he's a likable enough protagonist. It does have enough action to keep you interested. From helicopter chases to running through Madison Square Garden while being chased by dinosaurs. There are some fun characters and it can be pretty funny at times.Is it a pretty bad remake, yes it is. Is it a rip off of Jurassic Park, yes it is. Does it have flaws, oh it sure as hell does. But is it fun to watch. For me it was. Yes I can totally see people not liking this movie, I understand. But I enjoy it. Take it for what it is, and it's a fun movie to watch.</fullReview>
